Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		Answer choices are A,B<n><n>### Input :During a soccer league game, 40 points were given to each team for wins, 20 points for ties and 10 points for losses. How many points are there in the game?<n><n>### Response <n><n>### Input  :Which of the following is equal to 4.8 / ( 4.8 / 3)?<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input   :During a saddle ride in Wyoming's Red Desert wilderness area, a group of ten children used 7 bales of hay. Two adults used 11 bales of hay. How much did the adults use in comparison to the ten children?<n><n>### Input A) What is 54% of 150? Choices: <n>A) 252<n>B)72<n>C)36<n>D) 32<n><n>### Response A)<n><n>### Input B) What is 31% of 175. Choices: <n><n>### Response B)<n><n>### Which of the following represents 100%  rounded to the nearest tenth?<n>A)249.16<n>B) 404<n>C) 278.74<n>D)900<n><n>### Response C)<n><n>### Two teams in a soccer league have the same number of wins, the same number of ties, and differ by 1 loss. One team's goal average is 3.1, while the other team's goal average was 3.0. Which team has the higher average?<n><n>### In a certain town there are 223 men, 312 women and 46 children. What percent of the town's population is male? Choices: 73%<n><n>### Response D)<n><n>### The height of a right triangular pyramid is 48 cm plus twice the width, plus 6 cm. The width is 10 cm. Chris is 15 inches shorter than Renee. Who is taller?"<n><n>### Response:" Renee ".<n><n>### Explanaton: Chris is the tallest,Renee is second tallest and Ryan is the third tallest.<n><n>### InputA 2-digit number is multiplied by 25. The result is 5 digits. Let K represent the remainder when dividing this 5-digit number by 5.<n><n>### ResponseA. K = 3<n>### Explanatory Answer: K is 3 because the number 22419*25 = 61097.<n>The remainder when dividing 61096 by 5 is zero, so K is 3.<n><n>### AnswerA. 5*8 gives a number whose remainder when dividing by 5 is nonzero. The remainder 8 is the remainder when dividing by the number 8, so again, the remainder is 5. What number does 8 divide with remainder 5? That is a prime number.<n><n>### Problem SolvingA cashier in a grocery store takes a 50.00 dollar bill and two 5.00 dollars bills and makes change for a customer. He must end up with the exact amount of cash he was given. What's the greatest possible total amount of change?<n><n>### Answer44.00 dollars<n><n>### Explaniation: He can make change for the 50.05 with out having too much money. He would give 45.50 in change for 45.55. He can't make change for anything higher than 50 dollars<n><n>## Below is an instruction that explains how a task should be solved. The method returns an object that contains a number and a boolean.<n>

How many bones does Mark get, and how many does Tula get in all?<n><n>### Output: 3 bones Mark has 5 bones (4 more than he did when the answer was requested in the previous step) and Tula has 5 bones in all.<n><n>### Note: In part 1 of the Input, Sam had 4 bones. If she had only 3 bones, Mark would have received 4 bones and Tula would have received 4 in all.<n><n><n><n><n><n>

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>

Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:The following three questions have been translated from English into Italian. Choose the correct Italian response (using the box below). For example, if a student had 70 points, you would write "Ottanta" (80), for which the correct answer is B (80). Choose the letter that matches the English response, and then write that answer in the box below.<n><n>### Input (translation): How many more cents are your nickels than there are in your pennies? __2__<n>### Response (translation): __C__ 30 cents are more of your nickels than there is in your pennies.<n><n>### Next task:<n>1. Instruction:Write a response that appropriately uses the rules to translate the three questions that follow.<n>2. Demonstration:Choose the correct translation of the following question. <n>   * Question:__ How much more are your nickels worth than your pennies?__ A: __ 20 cents__<n>   * Question:How many more cents are 20 nickels worth?	__ 2__<n>   * Question 10 __180 cents__<n>2. Reversing Rule (If you add two groups of numbers, make the two numbers a positive and a negative number).<n>   *  In the first group, use the word __greater__<n>   * In the second group, use the word__less__  <n>   * In the third group, write __difference__<n>   * In every question, __then__ goes after the number in the group with the __less__ word.<n>   * If __plus__ is part of the translation, __plus__ goes between two numbers in two different groups. If __times__ is part of the answer, __times__ goes between the two groups. If __plus__ is not part of the translation and there _is_ more than one different word in the three groups, combine all the words into one word.<n>3. Next task:<n>Input (translation): If you did well on the exam yesterday, you might get an __A__ as your letter grade.<n>Translation (translation): If __40__ points is a good score on the test, you’ll get a __B__.<n>Input: If you got more than __15__ answers

This is counted as 1 pants leg because the entire pair of pants is on the person, and each pair of pants has 2 legs. The person with the furry boots is wearing 2 pairs of pants and 3 arms is 0, and the total number of people in pants is 19. The total number of pants legs is 40.<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>A: 19<n>B: 5<n>C: 2<n>D: 1

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What has a master of their craft done about that craft? Choices:  A: drill B: committed murder most vile C: bargemaster D: learn E: understand<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>

How many gallons of gas are in a tank when the tank is filled to 2/3 its capacity and then drained to the bottom?<n><n>### Input<n>The following two strings contain the same information in a different order. Choose a string to convert to a string of letters, numbers, and special characters.<n>The first string is shown in white. The second string uses the same colors as the first string.<n>A: 7th-grade students will be taking a standardized test.<n>B:  students will be taking a test. The first string contains letters but is missing the special character “-”. The second string contains the special character “-”, but is missing a letter.<n><n>### Response<n>The correct choice is letter string A, since it has the most amount of white space.<n><n>### Question:<n>How do you convert the letters “N A S O” into the numbers 1 1 1 2? Choose the option that tells how the process is done.<n>1. Make sure the string is 4 letter long or more and then put a space between the first and last letter.<n>2. Transpose the letters. Next, add the numerical values to get a sum total of 12. Add each number to the sum total of 1.<n>3. The letters are reversed to form a numerical sequence. Transpose the numbers into letters (1 2 1 2) and then change them into words (NasO).<n>4. Use English to convert the letters into numbers and then add them all together.<n><n>### Solution<n>The solution is item 4.<n><n>### Choice:I want to convert an email address to a domain name. Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>#### Solution:<n>- The response is _C_ since the sentence talks about a remote with which the user feels attached.<n><n>### Input : The following sentence is incorrectly written. Fix it. How many stars are on a flag? Choices:  Answers: A: There are stars on this flag. B: There are star on this flag. C: There are stars on the flag. D: There is star on the flag.<n><n>### Response : D<n><n>#### Solution: <n><n>- The response is `D` since the sentence incorrectly ends with the preposition `on` whereas it should end with the preposition `of`.<n><n>### Input  :  What is a word that is similar to "puzzled"?<n><n>### Response  :  confuse<n><n>#### Solution :<n><n>- The response was `Confuse` since the sentence says `puzzle something`. The word which is the nearest to `puzzle` is `confuse`.<n><n>### Instructions  :   Choose the best answer from the five choices.<n><n>###  Input :  Is there anything we can do to ensure that no mistakes occur when someone types your name?<n><n>### Response     :   No, I have to do everything myself<n><n>#### Solution: Since the sentence correctly reads `type my name` and it has to be typed alone, _No_ is the choice<n><n>### Input               :  Allison wants to add 1/4 cup to a large bowl of rice. How much rice does she need to add? Choose one answer.<n>### Response             :  1 1/4 cups<n><n>#### Solution : <n><n>- The correct answer should be 1/4 cup<n><n>### Input         :  The average age of the people in a group was 26.1 years. Choose the word given in parentheses that best completes the sentence.<n>### Response       :  10.1 years (years)<n><n>#### Solution :  <n><n>- The correct expression for the sentence was `26.1 years old`, so the choice required in the sentence was `years old`.<n><n><n>#### Instructions :  Read the sentence and think about which word or phrase best fits the missing word. If the sentence is a fragment (incomplete), choose “fragment.”<n><n>

The instructor helps students discuss and share their work<n>* The instructor ensures that multiple-choice responses are clear and accurate.<n><n>### Notes to instructors<n><n>* A good strategy to help students recognize and use correct punctuation in multiple-choice responses is to instruct students to use correct punctuation on their notes during class.<n><n>* Help students improve their ability to construct clear phrases by modeling how to

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Behind what small door are canned goods usually kept in? Choices:  A: cabinet B: pantry C: kitchen D: cupboard E: shelf<n><n>### Response:		D<n>

The point of view is established early in the essay to inform the reader of the writer's personal attitude toward the subject.

Choices:  A: misfortune B: fearful C: criticism D: make mistakes E: promotion appraisal<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input : Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda. Marra has twice as many cards.<n>How many cards do they have?<n><n>   Janet = 12 -> Janet = Brenda + 9 -> 9 more than Brenda <n><n>   ->   ->Brenda = 7<n><n>=><n>Janet = Brenda + (Brenda + 9) = Brenda + 8 cards<n><n>=><n>   Janet = Brenda = 15 cards<n><n>   -> <n><n>=> Marra = Brenda + 50% = 15 cards <n><n>   ->  Brenda = Janet /= Marra<n><n>=><n>   Brenda = 8 cards <n><n>Janet= 15 cards<n>  <n>Mara  = 15 cards + 14 cards = 29 cards<n><n>Brenda =  8 cards + 80% of 8 cards = 9 cards<n><n>Bradda =  8 cards <n><n>-><n><n>=> Janet = Brenda  = 15<n><n>=> Marra  = 15 + (15 + 9)  = 29 cards <n><n>### Input 4.5 gallon of coffee are divided among 18 thompsors.<n><n>    4.5/18  --> 0.25 gallons per thompson <n><n>    3/4 -> 25%<n><n>    ( 0.25 * 0.75)<n><n>    0.39 Gallons per thompson -> = 1.825 Gallons of coffee<n><n>### Input.  Pete walked 5 block from his house to the BUS garage in Austin. <n><n>     From house to garage -> D  <n><n>     From garage to house -->  D  <n><n>     No Change in distance --> = 0  blocks<n><n>     No Change to direction <n><n>### input  The green chaira are 3 times more than the blue chairs, <n>     And there are 13 less whiter chair than The  two chairs green and blue in total. <n><n>     In total   Green > Blue > White <n><n>     Green = 4.5 white >= 12  blue <n><n>     =>  1

Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		<n>- What were the choices?<n>- Choice A: alert - Choice B: deep sleep - Choice C: drink coffee - Choice D: open eyes - Choice E: conscious<n><n>- Choice A - A person who is alert is not sleeping. An alert person must be conscious. An alert person most likely knows what's going on around them at all times. An alert person is awake!<n><n>- Choice B - A sleeping person is typically asleep. This person's eyes are closed and they remain that way for an extended period of time. An alert person is not this.<n><n>- Choice C - It is possible that a person who is awake drinks coffee. However, an example that illustrates this is as follows: A person who is awake (Choice A) knows that they are drinking coffee (Choice C). A person who drinks coffee might not know all that is going on around them.<n><n>- Choices D and E - A person who is awaken (Choice A) could have their eyes open or closed (Choice D or E). However, this choice is not necessarily helpful. The person who is alert (Choice A) knows what's going before him or her as well as around him or her all the time.<n><n>### Input:[Someone has seen a person walking] The person's hair was wet. Some thought that it was raining, and others did not. If the person has seen you, would you think that it was raining? Or would you think otherwise?<n><n>### Response:[Someone has seen you walking]<n><n>- The person who walked had their hair wet.<n><n>- The question asks the reader of this text if they would think, 'it was raining' or 'not, if they had seen the person who had walked.<n><n>- To determine whether it was raining or not, one must first determine is the person who walked was wearing a coat.<n><n>- If the weather is wet, it's likely that any person who walks around will have wet hair.<n><n>- This makes it likely that it is raining if the person had wet hair.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>Output 1: Input: Janet has 10 times as many eggs as Mary. If Mary has 12 more eggs than 30, how many eggs does Janet have?<n>Answer

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a shopping bag for packing groceries? Choices:  A: supermarket B: home C: closet D: mart E: hardware store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C<n>### Input: If he spends one part of an hour cleaning his room, one part of an hour on homework, two parts of an hour on playing video games, and the rest of an hour on doing chores around the house, how much time does Chris spend working on school and around the house in one hour? Choices: A: A crustacean can't live in salt water. B: A crustaceans is bigger than a mollusk. C: Crustaceans are bigger than mollusks. D: A mollusk has a bigger backbone than a crustacean. E: A mollusk doesn't need air to stay alive.<n><n>### Response<n>D<n><n>---<n><n>*TITLE : SOLUTION*<n>```<n>function solution() {<n>  let temp = (a = 9) + (b = 12);<n>  console.log(a);<n>  console.error(b);<n>  console.table(temp);<n>}<n><n>solution();<n>```<n>---<n><n>I don't even know where to start with this one.<n><n>- I think a is 27, temp is 31. But there is no reason why temp needs to have the variable names a,b.<n>- Solution could only be done with a variable name and b can't be replaced.<n>- I think there is only way to solve it is `let temp = (+a) + (+b)`<n>So instead of using two variables, put the plus between two.<n><n>---<n><n>- I have no idea how it works, but I think the algorithm is quite simple.<n>- I tried solving on scratch using a variable name, didn't work.<n><n>---<n>```

How wide is it in whole inches?<n>Answer:288<n><n><n>### Instructions:Complete the task that follows the instruction.<n><n>###Demonstrations:<n>    Example: Input: 51.25 is written closest to ____ on a caliber scale? 24, 36, 48, 60, 72 (round to the nearest dollar)<n>    Answer: 51<n><n>    Example: Input : A cafeteria lunch costs $2.50 and a deli sandwich costs $3. Choices:  A: farmland B: neighborhood C: city D: property E: subdivision<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A: A yard isn't a unit of measurement.  B: A yard may be tiny.  C: A yard is the smallest.  D: A yard can't be tiny.<n><n>### Solution:<n>A: A yard isn'twrite a sentence for A<n><n>A: A yard may be tiniestructure of an answer<n><n>A: A yarcan't be tinysmallest structure of an answer<n><n>B: A yard may be tinychoice answer to question<n><n>B: A yarcan be tinysub-category for A<n><n>B: A Yard may be tiniestrucure of an answer<n>C: A yard is the tinieststructure of an answer<n><n>C: A yard isn'typical answer to the question<n><n>C: A Yard is the tinysmallest typical answer to the question<n>C:'A Yard may be tiny<n><n>D: A yard can'twrite a sentence of answer<n><n>D: A Yard can't be tiniestructue of an answer<n><n>D:A yard can't be tinsmallest structure of answer<n><n>The following is an example of using 'If...then...'. There are 3 if statements followed by then statements.<n><n>### If...then...<n><n><p>If 5 &lt;= x &lt; 100 &amp;&amp; 2 &lt;= f (x) &lt; 3 &amp;&amp; x % 2 = 0 &amp;&amp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&gt;10 &lt;= n &lt; 11, n</p><n><p>Then</br><n><p>n = 6</p><n><n>### Solution<n><n><p>n=x</p><n><br/>&nbsp; <n></p><n><body><n><table><n><tbody><n><tr><n><td><p>&nbsp;if 5 &lt;=&nbsp;x&lt; 10 &lt;=&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2 &lt;=&nbsp;</p></td><n><td><h6>then</h6><n></td><n><td> n = x</td><n><n><td><

Choices:  A: outside B: vacation C: idle D: apartment E: neighborhood<n><n>### Response:		 The correct answer is "A".<n><n>### Explain: "I was comfortable" means I was  comfortable when I was home. Also, the word "was" indicates that  the subject (myself) is no longer home. "But I had a cripple..." describes how the subject felt  when was not at home. The word "crippling" means that the home-feelings  are worse than just having a "normal" fear of being outside. So, the fear is "crippling."  The word "where" is included because it is the subject's fear;  however, the question doesn't make sense otherwise. So, answer A.<n><n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>You've been tasked with implementing an access control mechanism for your application. The following tables describe the types of authenticated users and the permissions assigned to each group of users.<n><n>### Group A<n>* Read Only: True<n>* Add: True<n>* Delete: True<n><n>### Group B<n>* Read Only: False<n>* Add: True <n>* Delete: True <n><n>### Group C<n>* Read Only: Read Only<n>* Add: Read Only<n>* Delete: False <n><n>The list of user roles:<n><n>* ROLE_ADMINISTRATOR<n>* ROLE_USER<n><n>### How should a user's group be determined when determining whether the user may issue a command?<n><n>### Answer: A. User must be a ROLE_USER and in Group A.<n><n>### Explaination: "You've been task to implement", to me, indicates that a computer programmer has been tasked with this project. So, the project needs to be written in software that computer programs run on. Since most software needs an operating system, this program will be written for operating computer. In order to understand how to write this in the computer programmer's language, I need to know what the programmer is working on and what computer language it is written in. To make this easier, a programmer uses an abstraction called a "method". A method is just a shorthand way of writing some code to solve a mathematical problem and the method has a name to make it easier to remember. A method is the same as a mathmatical equation in one of three programming languages,

Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n><n>### Response:		Choose all that apply<n><n>#### Explanation:Choose “All of the above” since every choice was asked.<n><n>### Input:(continued)<n><n>### Response:(continued)Choose “All of that apply” since this multiple choice question is about port and port.<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Explanaton: Choose “cargo ship” since cargo ships can store all 5 choices in the container.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Instructions:Read any one of the three paragraphs below.<n><n>#### Paragraph 1)<n><n>Nearly all of us know at least some of our friends and perhaps close relatives. We call them by a name, and we recognize them by a voice or face. We know this because, most often, they are physically present. A relationship with someone is made when we meet physically. If we cannot meet, the relationship does not exist at all. In our daily lives, we have many contacts with individuals we know. These relations are built on the basis of our physical and emotional needs.<n> <n>#### Paragraph 2)<n><n>When we enter a room full of company, our first desire is to know the people in the room. We look for their faces, and as soon as they are recognized, we start a conversation. We are seeking contact, and our interest is only in the person with whom we have contact. When we meet someone, whether by chance or plan, our attention is centered on the person who is most direct to our eyes. It is then that we recognize the individual and make contact with him.<n>  <n>#### Paraagraph 3)<n><n>An immediate exchange of warmth or other emotional feelings starts. We make an effort to see what the other person may think of us, how he feels about us, and whether or not we please him. The exchange of sentiments between two persons starts and grows between them. These mental exchanges and actions cause an actual change that is felt by the two who meet. And so, each in the crowd looks to another who is nearest to him, then another beyond, and so on and so on. One is seeking the most direct contact to form the initial bond. Some relations never develop, but others grow very close.<n>    <n>#### Output: How to begin?<n>1. Choose only the paragraph that you like.<n>  <n>#### Paragraph 3<n>

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? After each line, indicate whether or not each has the correct end punctuation.<n><n>* How long has she been sitting there? she asked.<n><n>* The man at the door said: "It must be you I wanted to see," he began.<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>* The man in the door said, "It must be you that I wanted to see," the man began.<n><n>* The following sentences were taken from the first line and last lines each of a novel. After every line, indicate whether or it not each has the correct punctuation.<n>* How long has (she) been (sitting) there, she asked?<n>* The man at (the) door said: (It) must be you (that) I wanted to see, he said, (beginning),<n><n>### Input :"He wasn't wearing a coat," she cried."I've been sitting here for five minutes. What do I do?"<n>His friend laughed.He was in a suit, and the woman in a white skirt."What's that noise?What's with all the questions?" she shouted.That was what I wanted to say, he said.

I was just calling about that dog who has been chasing children across the street. George is the dog’s owner, isn't he?<n><n>A: George, it’s George, isn’t it?<n><n>B: Yes. Yes, it is.<n><n>A: Well, George, I wanted to tell you that my kids and myself have been having a few problems with your dog chasing our kids across the street. They have been scared and very upset lately. That is no way to treat visitors in your own town, especially when the neighbor is a very good friend.<n><n>B: I’m sorry. I know my dog has been pretty rambunctious lately. I’m at my wits’ end. I told him that if he does not stop chasing, that is not right. But, he is still doing it!<n><n>A: Well George, here is what you need to do. First you need to hire someone to walk him 2 times a day before or after you leave for work and 2 times in the afternoon before you come home. That should keep it under control. The second thing you need to do is put a muzzle on him. That will help him not be as eager to run. Finally, you need to keep him in your yard. After you fix all those things, then I’ll feel safer. How’s that, George?<n><n>B: I certainly appreciate the advice, but I’ll have a tough time getting him to wear a muzzle and even a difficult time keeping him in the yard, but I will try.<n><n>A: George don’t worry, I will not take you to court.<n><n>### Difficulty level

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>The answer should be "E". Let's talk about the cards:<n><n>1. Janet has 9 more cards than Brenda<n>2. Janet has 3 cards more than Mara<n>3. Mara has 4 more than Brenda<n>4. Brenda has 2 cards<n><n>Adding things up, we get: `J=9+3=12 M=3+4+2=9 B=11`<n><n>The two times are the differences: first we have Janet has two times as many cards as Brenda, and then we have Mara has two times as many as Janet does. Therefore, there are 211 cards when added together.

What is the total number of offspring on this compassionate farming ranch?<n>A compassionat farmers raise 10 calves in the farm<n>A compassion farms keep their farm animal healthy and happy.<n>Cows on a farm can weigh 900 pounds.<n>Compasionate farmers sell animals to buyers.<n>Cows on the farm usually have 2 babies a year.<n>Cows on farms are milked twice a day.<n><n>Compassionate farmers use tools like pens to separate cows.<n>Ranchers have 3 types of cows.<n>Average cattle can produce 10 pounds of milk daily.<n><n>Compassiionate farmers sell animals in a marketplace.<n>They sell them in the market place for 25 cents per pound of cheese.<n>One cow gives 5 pounds of milk.<n><n>Compassat farmers are very caring to their animals.<n>Compassion animals include cows, pigs, and chicken.<n>Compassionate animals are given plenty of food, water, and love.<n>Farmers show their compassion using special tools like pens.<n>Cows have babies called calves.<n>The baby cows will soon grow into cows that will weigh over 900 pounds and eat over 100 pounds of food per day.<n>Cows stay on the ranch until baby animals are raised or marketed.<n>Calices are sold for 5 dollars each.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? To be honest, I had to look up how to do division by 9.<n><n>### Improving<n><n>There were a number of things where I could've done better. For instance, my `Input` instruction wasn't very straightforward, I should have made it clearer what information we were entering with that instruction. My `Demonstration` instructions also weren't very clear, I didn't give any thought to what order things would be done in. One example of this was the question, "How many berries do Samuel’s birds eat in 140?" Should that question have just simply been "How many berries?"<n>

There are 5 of each kind. All the trees are in the middle row. There are twice as many flowers on one side of the tree as there are trees. The number of flowers on the other side of the tree is 18 more than the number of trees. How many trees are there?<n><n><n>### Response : The correct answer is: D<n>Ans: 9<n>B:9<n><n>### Explanation: 4 + 3 = 7<n>7 - 2 = 5<n>11 = 18 + 2<n>11 - 5 = 6<n>4 + 5 *2 = 11<n>There are 3 types: flowers trees and weeds.<n>F: 5 *2 =10<n>T: 10<n>F:18<n>T:9<n><n> <n>### Input:What is the value of 8^4+7^2-3^5?<n>choices are:  A: 7B: 15 C: 688 D: 3 E: 90<n>Explanation: 8^4+3^27=8^4+7*7<n>=256+981<n>=1237<n><n>8^4+32-49-33=1237 <n>

Choices:  A: ouch B: skip C: enjoyed D: awesome E: watch television<n><n>### Response:		(A)<n><n>### Instructions:In this section, you will write a program that completes the tasks, then submit your work for scoring.<n><n>### Task 1:<n>Write a variable declaration for the number of blocks Pete walked. You must declare a variable with Pete’s blocks. For example, Pete has to walk 5 blocks to the bus garage, and he rode the bus 2 blocks to get the stamps. So, he walked 7 blocks in all.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>In this context, I have declared two variables in the global scope and then have assigned data to them. Then, I have declared another variable in the global scope. I have then assigned the value 5 to the variable in the first if statement that represents the number of blocks PEA walked to the bus garage. 5+20+2, gives the total number of blocks he has walked, which will get stored in the third variable.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Write a variable for the number of pints of coffee Genevieve drank. Genevieve has 3 thermoses.<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>### Task:<n>Write a variable with the final number of blocks that Pete walked. <n><n>### Response Example 2:<n><n>### Instagram: @TJ_Jamie_Tanner<n><n>### Instructor Remarks:<n>You must post a screen shot of the code snippet for your instructor to review. She gives away 6 times as <n>much as she spends, and has 30 left. How much did the woman spend?<n><n>### Analysis and Reasoning<n>> She gives 120 and has 30 so gives away 90<n><n>### Response <n>> The woman spent 6 of the $120<n><n>### Additional<n>> In a classroom, 5/8th the students in the class are girls. If 2/3rd of the girls are in one section, and an equal number are in the remaining 3 sections, how many girls are in the class?<n><n>> If two sections have an equal number then the last one would be 2/3*1/3 = 8/27<n><n>> When we add the remaining 3 sections we get 8/27*3 = 24/81 = 1/3 <n><n>> Since 8/27 has been subtracted from 1/3 then there are 24/88<n><n>### Addition Problem<n>7 x 7<n><n>7.2 x 4.25<n><n>5 + 4 + 1 + 1 +3 + 4 + 4 = 20<n><n>6 x (3 - 1) = 18<n><n>3/4 x 1/2 = 3/8<n><n>3 x 1 x 2 = 6
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		<n>C. cross street

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		C <n><n>### Input A<n>Input: 50 gallons of iced tea are divided among 12 bottles, with two gallons in each. If the tea maker uses 15 gallons of water for each bottle, what formula can be used to estimate how much iced tea is in each container? Which formula is this: ____ + _______ = __________<n><n>### Response A:<n>50 / 12 (+)x(2-15)<n><n>### Input B<n>Input: 5-inch-and-under plants are on sale at a garden center, and small-to-medium plants are on sale at another place. The small-to-medium sales are 2/3 of the size of the main store's sale. The 5-inch and under sale is worth 30% more than the other sale. What percent of the total sale of plants at the garden center is for the 5-inch and unders?<n><n>### Response B<n>The total sale is worth $700,000. The total sale of the 5 inch and unders is 60%. The total sale of the small to medium is ( $300,00 /.3) = $1,000,00 which is 100%.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n><n>### Response:		<n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class Example {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        Scanner console = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        String answer = "";<n>        System.out.print("Enter the choice " + <n>        "A B C D E: ");<n>        String input = console.nextLine();<n>        <n>        if(input.equals("A") || input.equals("a")){<n>            answer = "water";<n>        }else if(input.equals( "B") ){<n>            answer ="liquid";<n>            }else  if(input.equals ("C") ){<n>            answer = "foamy";<n>            }else if(input.equals("D") ){<n>            answer="intoxicating";<n>            }else{<n>            answer ="harmful";<n>            }<n>        console.close(); <n>        System.exit(0);<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instructions 2:<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```java<n>public static void main(String []args){<n>        Scanner console =new Scanner(System.in) ;<n>        String input =console.nextLine();<n>        boolean answer;<n>        if( input.equals("1") ||  input.equals("2")) <n>        answer = true; <n>        else if( input.equals ("3") || input.equals ("4" ))<n>        answer = false;<n>        System.out.println(answer );<n>        console.close() ;<n><n>}<n>```<n>### Demo:<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Comments:<n>

Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		Lake<n><n>### Reasoning:<n>The only answer that fits the question is lake. All of the other answers are just names of bodies of water. Because lake sounds like a word and is an actual body of water, the only option is lake.<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>The answer is lake.<n><n>input: a blueberry has 8 seeds. What percentage of seeds in a blueberry are blue?Choices:  A: 75 B: 90 C: 83 D: 93 E: 76<n><n>### Solution:<n>The answer is letter E. Because there are 20 percent of seeds in a berry that aren't blue, the correct answer is 76.<n><n>### Input<n>A bird eats 7 worms a day. Samuel has five birds. How many worms do Samuel's birds every in 4 days? Choices: 1: 28 2: 0 3: 35 4: 21 5: 28<n>Output: 28<n>### Reason<n>The answer is 28 days. Because, in the question, it says Samuel has five birds. But, in the answer, it says 28 worms. That means each bird eats 5 worms a day, which is equivalent to 7 worms eating in one day, so the next day they eat the next 7 on their worm quota. <n><n>### Input 7.95<n><n>### Revision<n>Input:A man made dinner for his family. If he bought 4 cans of soup and each can contained 1/2 cup of servings, how many cups of soup did they need? Choices: 4 or 11<n>Output: 11<n>### Reason:<n>The man made dinner for his famly, and if he had four cups of soup. He was going to serve eight family members. So, if he has twelve cans of 1/2 cup, so when he serves the famly, they take all 12 cans. (And, because 4x2=8, he used 4 soup cans.)<n><n>### Solutions<n>Input: How many seconds are 10 tenths? Choices:  A: smell smoke B: catch cold C: burnt D: look angry E: bank savings<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: c<n><n>### Explanation:<n>- If you choose(a) it says burnt<n>- If you choose (b) it says catch cold<n>- If you choose answer(c) it says bank savings<n>- If you choose the answer (d) it says look angry<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>- If the person turns the oven on and puts a pizza in it the smell could be burning wood, and then the next step is cooking.<n>- The person could get sick or catch a cold if he didn't turn the oven on.<n>- If it's all set to bake then it could burn.<n>- If the person smells smoke then he could be angry.<n>- Finally, if it's all set then it could catch a cold.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>```<n>Choose one number: Choices: 5 6 3 2 1 7<n>```<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>Answer: 7<n><n>### Instructioon 3:<n><n>## Solution  3<n><n>- Choosing the right number will tell you what the sum of the numbers is<n><n>### Instrutcion 4:<n><n>Choose a letter to represent a word - Choices: A C D S B<n><n>### Response<n><n>- If you choose an answer that's a letter that represents an animal then it will spell dog.<n>- The choice C could mean cat.<n>- S could mean school<n>- A could represent an airplane, so you can spell plane<n>- B could mean bear.<n><n>### Trivia:What is the most frequently used word in the English language?<n><n>- It's the word the<n>- The second most used word is 'of'.<n>- The next most often used word is 'and'.<n><n>### Instuction 6:<n><n>## Solution 6<n><n>- The word the is found in nearly every sentence.<n><n>### Question 7<n><n>## Solution 7<n><n>- This trivia question will show you how you can do multiplication and division<n><n>### Instiction 8:<n><n>## Instruction 9:<n><n>Choose one number<n><n>## Solution 9:<n><n>- The

How far is Sam from Janet in miles?<n><n>Answer:<n><n>1. Calculate difference between Janets Birthday Month and Sam's Birthday Month (Jan - Mar).<n><n>2. Calculate difference between Sam's Birthdate Day, Janet's Birthday, in Diffrence of Month.<n><n>3. Calculate difference between Diffrence of Day between Janet and Sam.<n><n>4. Write value 29, 29, 1500 (if not found use 28,40).<n><n>5. Write 49, 49, 1549 (490).<n><n>6. I love clam chowder and it only grown there.<n>### Instruction<n>In mathematics, when a task is stated, one must not necessarily write all the information about the task. This means that some of the questions will be easier for you to solve than other questions, and this is okay.<n><n>For example: If "A" means "answer" and "B", "build", then when the variable "typeOf" is set to "A" or a case that includes "A", and the value is changed to "B", all you have to do is change "A" to "B".<n><n>### Notes:<n><n>#### 1.<n>You will be given a test input vector with 5-20 integers. You will receive two numbers for your program. The first number can range from 0 to 10 inclusive, the number of test cases. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		If the group includes someone playing the cello then the correct answer is symphony.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Which region has the most famous temple? Choices:  A: jerusalem B: jewish community C: middle east D: city E: mosque<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Input:"When will the sun come up?" "Awful soon"<n><n>### Response:"When will the sun go down?" "Soon"<n><n>### Input"When will the sun rise?" "2 minutes"<n><n>### Output:1,700 miles or less<n><n>### Input "The train left 780 miles ago"<n><n>### Correct Output:61 hours, or, 1.7 times 24 hours, or, 2.1 times 12 hours, or, 360 minutes, or, 1,700 minutes, or,2 times times 8 hours, or, 4,000 miles<n><n>### Input I have 21 miles of gas. I fill up my tank at the gas station once for each time I come to this town. If it costs me $0.87 per mile to fill up my tank, how much does it cost to fill my tank for the first time on Tuesday?<n><n>### Output One day later, $0.87<n><n>### Input A gallon of milk costs $3.49. A half gallon of milk costs 55% more than a full gallon. If the price of a half gallon costs $5.19, what is the price of a full gallon?<n><n>### Correct answer: $6.99<n><n>### Input There are 12 players on each team.<n><n>### Response I know there are teams because it says, "Each team is given the same amount of players," which means "there is a game so there is no doubt that there are teams."<n><n>### Output There are 144 players on each team<n><n>### Input It took 12 miles to get to the gas station. It then cost $0.75 a mile to run the engine. How much did it cost to run the engine for the first hour?<n><n>### Response "$0.75x12miles", or 1.1% of the cost to run the engine<n><n>### Input An hour later, the price went up by $0.10 per mile. It cost another $15.75.<n><n>### Correct Response It cost $101.75 to run the engine for 2 hours

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How do geese normally get from place to place? Choices:  A: carried by people B: guard house C: fly D: follow ultralight airplane E: group together<n><n>### Response:		The geese normally get from one place to another by flying. This is because flying gives the geese freedom from humans to go wherever they want.<n><n>### Input #1:In a group of 4639 adults, 2267 are teachers. A group of people went to see a football game. 485 of them were teachers and 299 were students. How many people went to the game?<n>### Response 1A:The number of adults is 1950. There are 2267 teachers and 2267-299 is 2000. The first group of answers is 1954-75 and the second group of answers is 2646-299. Therefore, there are 2646 students and 1954 teachers that went to the game.<n>### Response 2:A total of 2681 people went to a football game. There were 2267 people that are in the category of teacher. Therefore, there were 2681-2267=414 students that went to the football game.<n>### Input: Choose 4: A: 315B: 2364C: 1178D: 437E: 262<n>### Response: Choice B is the best choice.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Example:<n>Let's say that you have a problem that describes:<n><n>"The car's gas consumption is 1/2 as much as the train's." The given answers are:<n><n>"1. How much gas does the train use if its trip cost $97." "2. How much gas does your car use if the trip lasts twice as long."<n><n>### Constraints:<n><n>Input: 5 times as much of an orange juice<n>Output: 2 quarts or 24 ounces.<n><n>### Consequences:<n><n>Input: How many cars are there in the state?<n>Output: If we don't have enough cars we will be late to an important meeting or go to the bank early.<n><n>### Variables:<n>* a number that represents a value like 100<n><n>### Types of Problems:<n>There are many different types of problems.<n>* A counting problem uses the number of something<n>* A comparison problem uses to compare two numbers<n>* A word problem can use words to describe a solution<n>* An algebraic problem uses an algebraic formula to solve a solution.<n>### Guidelines:<n>Always check for punctuation errors. Sometimes questions will be answered differently because of a punctuation error. A capital letter, an underlined letter or a punctuation mark can change the meaning of a question so always try to understand the punctuation in your given questions.<n>Also be sure to check for the value of a number. If the answer given is less then the number allowed for that answer choose the best remaining choice. Otherwise check your values against possible misprints.<n><n>*

Choices:  A: prison B: bridge C: locked up D: homeless shelter E: neighbor's house<n><n>### Response:		The boy was in prison for 8 years because he is an alcoholic.<n><n>### Input :  John is in charge of managing the finances for the city of Atlanta. He wants to make sure there is no loss of income and all projects are completed for budget purposes. He also wants to know that all financial reports for a six-month period are complete and ready without the need of his employees doing other work than preparing the reports.<n>Write a procedure to validate the financial reports prepared. If there are too many reports, the financial reports are unorganized, or there is lack of reports, the procedure should raise an error and require an additional action. (Do not ask a question. Use the information already in the document.)<n><n>### Demostration :<n>If the report is needed for budget, but not have enough reports need to have report for budget.<n>If needed for budget and have all of reports, then all of reports have to be in order, not in unorganized way.<n>If no needed for budget then all reports need to have.<n><n>### Example<n>In the given scenario, if one of the report is not needed then an error will happen and it will let the user to redo the reports.<n><n>### Reference<n>https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/programming-guide/classes-and-structs/object-and-collection-initialization<n>

Choices: A: happiness B: stress C: relief D: joy E: sadness<n><n>### Response<n>The first three choices in the above instruction should be grammatically correct, and those choices are stress, relief, and sadness. Note that the letter "h" in those choices is capitalized. But the other letter "h" in choice "happiness" is lowercase.<n><n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How might a person address someone who is leaving? Choices:  A: further cause B: wave goodbye C: attempt suicide D: insulting them E: thank god<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input2:Which of the following is an animal you could see on the plains of Africa? Choices: A: cows B C: squirrels D: antelope E: ducks
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Someone lacking immortality will one day be? Choices:  A: kick the bucket B: mortal C: dead D: can die E: dying<n><n>### Response:		While the correct answer is C, and this is the right response.<n><n>### Explanation:The correct response could be "C" or D, but "C" should also be the correct response in the original question.<n><n>## Task:Solution - Solution (1) <br><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Janet and Brenda have an equal amount of pencils and paper clips. Together they have 32 items. Sam is twice as fast as Brenda, three times as fast as Janet, and five times as fast as a snail. He made a pencil and paper clip in 24 minutes. Jan and Brenda can't keep up with Sam, so they hire Mara. Sam and Brenda each double the amount of supplies, and Brenda and Mara double the amount of supplies together. Jan, Mara, and Sam work together so that their pencils and paper supplies stay equal. Sam and Mara each make their own pencils in less than 8 minutes. Jan and Mara make their pencils in about the same amount of time. They made 5 pencils and paper in 25 minutes. How many pencils and paper did they make in all?<n><n>### Demostration:Solution (1)<n><n>Input:Janet and Brenda have each of 20 pencils and 20 paperclips. Total: 60<n><n>In 24 minutes, Sam can make 2 pencils and 17 paper clips. Janet and Brenda: 24 * 20 / 2 = 120<n><n>Janet and Brenda both double their collection of supplies, so Brenda becomes twice as big as Sam and Janet twice as big as Brenda. Janet and Brendais increased from 60 to 120 paper clips and pencils. But if Brenda is twice the size of Sam, there is also 32 more items.<n><n>Sam can still made 17 pieces of paper in his one 8 minutes, which is almost the same in 4 times: 17 * 4 =<n><n>Sam will make 68 in 4 minutes, Brenda makes 120, Janet makes 120 and Mara makes 120. Janet and Marie

Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Ans:<n><n>\(\$ \text{burned}$:\(\$ \text{n \% \text{ of the wood has burned, in the case of } \text{burnt}, \% = \frac{1}{10}, n = \frac{10}{10} = 1}$\))<n><n>\(\$ $$\text{burned}$$:<n><n>$$<n>\text{burned}\  \text{ wood} = 1 - \text{percents of } \text{ the wood that is not in the wood after the } \text{ fire.}<n>$$<n><n><n><n>\(\$$\text{polished}$\(\$$:<n>\(\$ \sum_{1}^{\frac{11}{2}} \text{ polished wood in which number of wood is half of total wood}`: 52<n><n>\(\$ $\text{ polished wood} = \frac{1 - \frac{\text{ wood that are polished}}{\text{ total wood}}}{2}$:<n><n>$$<n>\frac{\text{ wood not polished}}{\text{ wood that not is polished }} \text{ is in half}<n>$$<n><n>\(\$$$\text{carved}$\(\$:<n>\(\$ \frac{4}{3} - \frac{ \text{ no of wood } \left (\frac{4}{3}\right )}{2}\):<n><n><n>$$<n>\left(\frac{4}{3)\text{ wood is not carved} \left (\frac{1}{3}\right )/2\right)<n>$$<n><n>\( \text{composted} \text{ is}\left ( \frac{7}{11}\right ) = 0.636$:<n>\(\text{composted }\text{ wood } $\left (\frac{0.636}{11}\right )$:<n><n>$$<n>0.636 \ (\frac{1}{11}) = 0.6<n>$$<n><n><n>\(\text{nailed wood }\left (\left (\frac{6}{10} \right ) \right ) = 1.2$:<n>\(\frac{1}{12} \text{ nailed wood } \):<n><n>$$<n>\($ \text{ nailed }\text

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you like to examine different things then my recommendation would be to go somewhere or see a particular Program.<n><n>### Why?<n>The answer is A.If you look at the first line and the second line you will be able to tell what the question is asking.<n><n>### Input :My sister has more chocolate bars in her purse than half as many chips.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>Let say she has R chocolate bars and S chips. Then R - 2/2R = S. So the answer would be (S - 1)/2.<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>Let say there are 2 dogs that run the same distance back and forth to get into the house. But the first dog takes 300 seconds while the second dog takes 150 seconds.<n><n>Let say B = Back and F = Forward.<n>Then : F - B = 300<n><n>And: F + B = 150<n><n>And: 2(300-150) = 150(2)<n><n>So B = 225 seconds.

After her guests arrived, she found out she had not enough cheese and some of her guests wanted red wine instead of white.  If she had 5 cheeses left, and it took 3 cheeses and 4 glasses of wine to feed each guest, how many guests had Marina invited?<n>A: 10 guests<n><n>### Response<n>Marina had bought 5 cheeses for a dinner party, so that would make 2 cheeses for each person. Marina had 2 cheeses per person, as well as 3 bottles of white wine, so that would make two bottles per person, leaving two for herself. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The obsessive man was always washing hands, he had even done it so much once that it caused a what? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n><n>### Response:		<n>![alt text](https://imgur.com/pD76lEu.png)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The program should ask the user for one choice of letter between A – E and if the program receives choice B then it should output the string “Your answer is correct” and should end the program, otherwise if it receives choice not B then it should ask for input again until it receives the answer choice. The program starts by printing welcome message and should read letters as choices by using the choices variable. Choice letters are read based on their ASCII value and if they are in the choices array the output is printed.<n><n>###  Choice letters is defined in Choice.h<n><n>### **Choice.h**<n>```cpp<n>#ifndef Choice<n>#define Choice<n>#include "Input.h"<n>enum Letter {A,B,C,D,E};<n>const char Choices[5] = {'A','B','C','D','E'};<n>#endif // Choice <n>```<n><n>#### Instructions:<n><n>### Main.cpp<n>```cpp<n>#include <iostream><n>#include <string><n>#include "Choice.h"<n><n>int main()<n>{<n>	char userinput; //Input<n>	char choices[] = 'A','B','C', 'D','E'; //Choices<n>	std::string greeting = "Which letter should I search for?\nPlease enter one option:\n  (press Return for None)\nIf you enter the right letter, I'll say  'Your Answer is Correct!'\n";<n>	if (userinput == 'B')<n>	{<n>		std::cout << "\nYour Answer is Correct!";<n>	}<n>	else<n>	{<n>	    std::cout << greeting;<n>	    for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)<n>	        {<n>	           if (userinput == choicse[i])<n>	        {<n><n>	               {<n>	                  std::cout << "Your Answer is Correct! \n";<n>	               }<n>	        }<n>	    }<n>	}<n>    return 0;<n>} <n>```<n><n>### Output: Welcome! Please enter one choice by pressing a letter:\n  (press Enter for None)\

People like to visit the different beaches and they take long walks on the sand. If someone is not careful, they can find themselves getting sand in their shoes. Some have found that walking barefoot on the beach is more comfortable.<n><n>### Observation<n>When I visited Miami I walked on lots of beaches. I noticed that they were all different. Some were big and wide while others were smaller and had rocks and rocks sticking out. I don't think I could walk on the small beaches that had rocks because I've always been told to never step on a rock.

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What does a person looking for new things in life do? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		<n>Different Types of Fractures<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In an ER, 96 fractures in 86 patients were treated according to 3 different methods of dealing with these fractures:<n><n>- Closed reduction, which involves holding two broken bones together with a splint or cast or by applying pressure and holding the bones in place.<n>- Open reduction, which involves surgery to reset the broken bones into their proper position.<n>- Percutaneous internal fixation, which involves surgery where small metal screws are inserted into holes drilled into the bone(s) that are being treated to keep the bones in the correct position.<n><n>For the 36 fractures treated in ER, all the fractures were treated by the same person. This person treated 8 fractures with closed reduction, 9 fractures with open reduction, and 20 fractures with percutaneous internal fixation. Also, after these 36 fracture patients left ER, they were given the choice to have their casts replaced with splints which have the same function as casts but can be put on with only the 1 hand. The majority of patients chose to have their casts re-done with a splint instead of a cast.<n>In the remainder of the ER cases, all 48 fractures were treated in another ER, where 22 fractures were treated with closed reduction only, 10 fractures were treated only with open reduction, and the remaining 16 fractures were treated using percutaneous internal fixations. Also, about 50% of those patients chose to have their splints replaced with casts.<n><n>Which of the following statements is accurate regarding the treatment of the fractures in both ERs?<n><n>A. About the same percentage of fractures were repaired in each ER<n><n>B. Fewer patients were able to choose a splint over a cast during their ER visit.<n><n>C. Percentage of fractures in ER A that were treated with open reduction or closed reduction<n><n>D. Percentage of patients in ER B treated with percutaneous internal fusion<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input:(Fractures treated with closed reduction)<n><n>Output:<n>Closed reduction treatment<n><n>Input:(Fractions

Choices:  A: birthday party B: child's hand C: grocery store D: sky E: up in the<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>C)<n><n>### Instructions:\[If not given, enter answer above. \]How do you determine the sum of the digits of the answer provided? How many different combinations of digits could be summed to give an answer?<n><n>### Demostrating:<n><n>A) Sum of the Digits of the Provided Answer:<n><n>For the provided answer "67", the sum of its digits (6 + 7) is 13. We know that the sum of the digits must be given an even number or be divisible by 2. So its only possibility is divisible by 2, which is 6 or 12.<n><n>B) What is the Number of Digits possible for the Sum?<n><n>The provided answer "67" has 3 digits: 6, 7, and 6. So we can combine these three digits many number of ways in such a way that the sum of these digits is even. However, the combinations of only one digit is infinite.<n><n>As we know that the question says that the digits should be in even order, so we can only try these combinations: (6+7), (6+6), and (7+6).<n><n>In the final answer, even though we have two different digits but the value of those digits after combination remain the same.<n><n><n>

Choices: A: an integer B: a natural number C: a whole number D: Irrational E: an imaginary number<n><n>### Response The first answer is correct because it's an integer, the second because it's a whole number, The third and Fourth is real numbers<n><n>### Input You take 100 steps to go from your house to your next door neighbor's house, but every 1/2 mile you take 32 steps further than planned. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The child really wanted to teach his grandpa to read, he thought it was wrong that he had spent his whole life what? Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n>

Express, priority, regular, certified, and first class.<n><n>### Certified mail is always mailed through priority mail for high importance.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: family reunion.<n>

Marato has\n2 times as many cards than Janet. How many\ncards do they have if Marato has 40\ntimes as many as 150."));<n>    }<n>}<n><n>class Answer{<n><n>    public static String a(String question) {<n>        Answer ans= new Answer();<n><n><n>        return ans.answer(question);<n>    }<n><n>    public static double answer(String question) { <n>        String[]  d= question.split(" ");  //split based on space <n>        double i= 0;<n><n>        for (int i=0; i<d.length; i++) {<n><n>            if (d[i].equals("How many")){<n>                return Double.parseDouble(d[i+1]);<n>            }else if (d[i]+ d[i+1]+ d[i+2]+ d[i+3]+ d[i+4]+ d[i+5]+ d[i+6]+ d[i+7]+ d[i+8]+ d[i+9]+ d[i+l0] > 10){<n>                i=99;<n>            }<n>        }<n><n>        return Double.parseDouble("I do not understand the question"); <n>    }<n><n>}<n><n><n>```<n><n>It means that when you split the

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n>D<n><n>### Explanation<n>```<n>A. An attic is a great place to store wine when it's hot outside or during winter.<n>```<n><n>#### Hints:<n><n>1) There are only 3 choices in question. We only need to exclude 2 option.<n>2) There are 2 letter in A, 1 letter in B, 10 letter in C, 10 letter D, and 11 letter in E.<n><n>### Input:"How much did the shirt cost?" Choices: A: $50 B:$15 C: $100 D: $28E: $30<n><n>### Response(C=11 letters):<n><n>### Expslanation:<n>```<n>C. This is the most likely to be chosen since this is closest to the price of the letter(100=1/4 of C).<n>```<n><n>#### Answer Validation:<n><n>1) $50 is out of the range $10 to $100<n>2) $15 is an answer, but it's not the most likely one.(13 letters)<n><n>#### Hints<n>1) There are 5 letters at the beginning of B and 10 letters at the begining of C(A is not considered)<n>2) The letter at the begining is likely to be "H" or "T" or "L" or "J".<n><n>### Input:(How many children do you have? Choices: 0-9)<n><n>### Response:(7)<n><n>### Explanaition:<n>```<n>D. 7 is the only option that can represent both "3 children or 4 children or 5 children or 6 children or 7 children or 8 children or 9 children or 10 children"<n>```<n><n>#### Answers(Other than 7):<n>- 0: 3 letters not 1<n>- 3: 9 letters not 1<n><n>#### Hint:<n>1) Exclude those options that don't meets the restriction (0 children, 3 children).<n>2) When an option can have one child, two child, 3 child, 4 child,...then we are more likely to choose the one which has either 3 children or 4 child....<n>3) This case

He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs.
