How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In order to answer the first multiple choice question, we are required to subtract 9 from 15 since Janet has 9 more than brenda. The second question also requires us to subtract 2 x's from 15 since mara has double the amount of x's as janet. For the third question, I assumed they needed to multiply one side by 3 and subtraite on the other side. This allowed me to divide the green by blue and subtract 3 from the total. The fourth question asks to do the opposite of multiplication and division. The fifth question involves multiplication since alannah has 21 more books than beatrix and queen, and all together has 20 more than beatrix. The final question deals with addition since samuels birds have 20 x 5 = 1 double edge razors.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>1. How many gallons of water are there in the United States? Choices: A: 5 million gallons B: 5 trillion gallons C: 5 million tons D: 50 trillion gallons E: 50 thousand trillion gallons<n><n>2. In the Great Lakes, there are the largest five (lakes Huron, Ontario, Superior, Michigan and Erie). If the greatest lake of the five is equal to the smallest, which lake is the greatest? <n><n>### Response to the above question<n><n>We first convert the volume of the water needed to understand the volume more. Water does not really have weight, but takes up space. As a result 5 million gallons are one billionth of the volume of the U.S. water supply with 381 billion gallons. We can then simplify the next choice, which is 50 million billion and just as much water. The simplest answer that is chosen is B, because of the great distance between the answer choice of the lake of the least and the greatest of the five lakes. Because this makes it easier for me. To do the rest of the question I just add all the answers up. To answer with 5 x 50 x 50 x x, then x, i chose to leave a space between the variables to just get the answer.

Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Whenever we are asked to solve problems using math, it is always wise to start by writing down the given information so that we can see how we are required to solve the problem.<n><n>From the given information we learn that A is already dancing and doing it progressively, and that B is standing still (cause if they were dancing, then it would contradict in the first input).<n><n>Then using the information we can draw this equation, a + b = c + d = e<n><n>So solving we have a = 0 which is the boy is standing still, and b + d + e = 0 so e must have 50% of c which means it is B or C because it has no overlap<n><n>### Instructions: Find all combinations that meet the requirement.<n><n>Input: There are four colors to use on the soccer ball. There are three reds less than 7 reds. There are three yellows times as many yellow as blue. How many reds, yellows and blues are there altogether to use on the ball?<n>Answer: 75<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Though he was an adult he still stereotypical slept on a sofa bed in his parent's what Choices:  A: garage B: horseradish C: living room D: guest room E: basement<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>    if choice == 'A' :<n>         print("garage")<n>    elif choice == 'B' :<n>         print "horseradish"<n>    elif choice =='C' :<n>         print ("living room")<n><n>    elif choice == D :<n>         print ("guest room")<n>    elif choice== 'E':<n>            print("basement")<n>    else:<n>         print ("please try again")<n>```<n><n>### Demostrataion<n>```python<n>    Answer = 100<n>    print("Answer:",Answer)<n>```<n>### Instuction:<n>Explain how you used the previous prompts when writing your solution.<n><n>**Input:** Though he was an adult he slept on a sofabed in his parents garage.<n><n>**Response:** The above prompts were used when  i answered the question using a code in which you must give a response to a choice of options that were given. We were cooking between 60 and 80 meals at this point everyday, so I learned how to properly stock the kitchen and make sure everything was set on the back end. I had many challenges and had to come up with a system that worked, which helped with making sure that we had the right tools when we needed it. The biggest challenge was staying on top of inventory because if we ran out of supplies at one time, we sometimes couldn't get it in because we were already over halfway done with another meal.<n>"<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		What is the input? Write the correct choice as a word.

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:(This is just a quick example)<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>What is the value of x in the equation:<n>x+(4x+5) = 9x+8?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>x = 2, (because 9x+8 can be simplified to 1<n>x+4x+5 = 9x+9, so 4x+5 =1<n>10x = 18, and x = 8/10<n>8/10 (8/10 + 4*8/10 +5) = 9/10 x 8/10 +8/10, so x=2/10<n><n>### Instuction:<n><n>What is the value in x that makes the equation 11x + 48 and x+11x -8 true?<n><n>###Demostration:<n><n>x:8, because (11x - 8)(x+11x+8) = 1<n><n>###Input: (Again, this is just a quick example.)<n><n><n><n>###Instructions:<n>If we write (n)(a + b) = m(a + b) as an equation, what do the parentheses mean?<n><n>###Response: The parentheses are used to change the order of arithmetic.<n><n>###Demonstration:(A quick example)<n><n>If we wrote (n)(29 + 13) = m(29 + 14), m and n are both variables. <n>n = a number, a =1 number in an expression (n)(29+13)<n>29 is the constant, and 13 is the variable. In m(29 +14), the parentheses around m show that m is a variable.<n>14 is the number in m's parentheses and a+b is the second part of the multiplication<n>(n) shows that a is a multiplicant<n>(n)(a+b) shows that b is the product of the multiplicant and multiplier and a is the first term.<n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>>A: intelligence<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>An inability to learn is a condition or an inability to learn. It could be a mental issue or a physical issue. <n>Mental issues would include, but are not limited to dyslexia, Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, dyscalculia, and dementia.<n>Physical cause would include but not limited to hearing loss, blindness, and physical impairment. <n><n>The inability to learn has many causes. Here is one of the most important cause, a mental cause. The causes that lead to the failure of learning and/or understanding the information presented in a learning situation are due to different cognitive processes. For example, cognitive processes such as memory (or the storage and use of information), perception (or the ability to detect changes and different sensations), and psychomotor (or movements related to the thoughts or the movement of one's body) (Cambria & Aiken, 2010).<n><n>The inability of persons to learn in different situations could be the result of two types of inabilities <n><n>1. Inability to store the information in memory.<n><n>2. Inability to retrieve the information from memory<n><n>In both inabilities, if the learner does not store the information properly or to the extent that a learner needs to have, this inability will affect a learner's ability to retrieve the information needed for the task or the learning situation being experienced. Furthermore, this inability could also result in a learner having difficulty performing the task or learning the subject.<n><n>>B: education<n><n>### Exclamation:<n><n>>B: D<n><n>This statement is incorrect because a stupid person would have a low mental ability. So he could learn a lesson about an inability to learn even with education. <n><n>A stupid person's ability to learn or retain information is not dependent on his educational qualification, for example, not having an education. So, the learning outcomes in a learning situation or the level of learning would be low, not because of the stupidity of a person/learner but because of a poor learning background. <n><n>### Input<n><n>>What might low intellectual skills of students cause? Choices: A: failure of students in classes B: students do not like school C: students fail exams

Choices:  A: nice feeling B: good karma C: respect D: new freedom E: good heart<n><n>### Response:		<n>* A: *<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the next sentence correctly.<n><n>### Response<n>* The next sentence:I am forgiving!<n><n>### Instructuon:<n>Complete the question that best follows.<n>Which of the following statements comes closest to describing how one person might begin thinking about forgiveness? Choices: A: Forgiveness will not happen unless I see it as something I need to do for other people B: I have to find the other person who wronged me and say forgive me C: Forgiving myself will help me accept who I am. D: I need to feel good about myself before I can forgive others.<n><n>### Responses <n><n>### Answer:<n>Because of the question words What, then,..., and then...<n><n>### Instruption: Complete the list with 6 words.<n><n>In addition, there are four parts of the question; the word What is the first word, the word then is the second word, the word... is the third word, and the word then is the fourth word.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>### Instraction: Complete the story, using the 7 words from the box below.<n><n>### Incompletion:<n>I used to be afraid of people laughing at me. I was always afraid they would tell everyone to leave me alone. I thought everyone liked me; in  grade school, I thought my grades were good. But my teacher would get mad all the time. But one time she said I was not good enough. I thought I could not do anything. I tried to do what they wanted, but I was wrong. I realized everyone made fun of me, and it was not my fault. Then I felt that it was ok to laugh at them. They had not understood anything. I could see them. I decided to be happy. I wanted to help everyone by my presence: not only was I happy; I felt good towards everyone. I decided not to be angry or sad if I saw their faces; I said to myself, you are happy because I know you are happy inside. Now everyone feels welcome and can be happy. I still feel the same but I am happy.<n><n>```<n>(1)<n>```<n><n>### Increment of the sentence:<n>I was afraid of people laughing and would tell everyone to leave. In grade school, I thought

Choices:  A: ink in B: caps C: ink cartridges D: take notes E: scribble<n><n>### Response:		<n>D -> Take notes<n><n>### Input : A bird eats 20 berries every day. If Berries are 35 cm in length 5cm wide and 4cm deep, how many berries fit in a cup?<n><n>### Response :<n>B -> 1 Berry<n><n>### Input  : If the sum of your age and your wife's age is 78, how old is your wife?<n><n>### Demosc:<n>A (70)<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>If a + b=88, and a - b = b, what is the value of b?<n>```<n><n>### Solution<n>A = 80 //88-88 =80<n>a-b=10 //b=10<n>b=10<n><n>```<n>If your sister is 3 years older than you are, and you are 4 years older than your brother, how old is your sister?<n>```<n><n>A =27<n><n>### Input3<n><n>```<n>John can complete a job in 2 days, while Steve can do it in 4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In this problem Janet has 9 less than Brenda, and Mara has twice as much as Janet. So the answer is 191 and the option 4 is correct.<n><n>In this problem Pete walked 5 block from house to bus garage, he rode the bus 2 times the distance between point A and B, and he went back the same way. Hence the answer is 200 and the option 5 is correct.<n><n>We can eliminate options A and C because Janet has 9 more than Brenda. So by taking 9 away will give 9 or negative value. So, option B and D are excluded because we take away numbers in options A, B, and C, which is lesser than 0. Hence, option E, which is 19 and 13.<n><n>In this question, we will not allow for negative number as in the 4 and 5 option, because 6 and negative number is not allowed. Hence, for the question and for input question the exposition is option E.<n><n>In this questions, the answer is not 10, because Alannah has 30 book if Alannah have the answer, then Beatrix have the answer as well. Alannah is lesser than Beatrix. So, 10 will be too small for the answer. Hence, the answer is 250 and the option C is correct.<n><n>### Outcome:<n><n>### Notes:<n>**Congratulations! You have finished this course on How to Solve Multi-Step Word Problems on Algebra 1!**

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The man went to clown college, he had always want to run away with the what? Choices:  A: circus B: carnival C: surprise D: spoons E: party<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explain:Answers:<n>Because if a man who wants to run away with the circus can also be with someone.<n>### Input:A car dealership has 14 pickup trucks and 80 crossovers for sale. 5 different customers come to the dealership and test-drive each vehicle they want to buy. One day, 5 different customers come in to test drive all 88 vehicles which one or more test-drive each truck for a total of 250 test-drives. How many hours does every dealership vehicle have been test driven in total?<n><n>Answer:<n><n>### Input-The same amount of money goes to one or more of the 5 accounts. Choices: A:  $100 B: $500 C:  $10500 D: $5000<n><n>### Response-A<n>### Explain The correct answer is:<n><n>100<n><n>## Explanation:<n><n>  The amount is the same amount of money goes out of one or more of the accounts. This means that if one hundred dollars that goes out of one account then one hundred dollars goes out of the other account too.<n><n>### Input--The amount of money that goes into the bank is the same as the amount that goes out. Choices: A:$20 B:  $50 C:  $200 D: $100<n><n>Answers-$100<n><n>   $$100 = 200$$<n><n>  $$200 =100$$<n><n>## Explanations:<n><n>$$100 = 300$$<n>$$300 = 100$$<n>if $$100$$,$$200$$,$$300$$,$$400$$.$$100 =$$300$$$$100 = $$500$$$$192 =$$400$$$$1=$$92$$<n><n>### This is a picture. <n><n>![alt text](https://github.com/xavierrodriguez/xavier-rodriguez.github.io/blob/master/images/instructions.jpeg "Instructions")<n><n><n>![Alt text](https

How much water is in the cup? <n>- I would take the volume of 2.5 and 1.5 for the initial cups, then subtract the two answers and that would be the answer.<n>- 1.5 - 2.5 = 1<n>- So 1 is how much water is in the cups (cup A + cup B = 1 cup)<n>- Or I can simplify the problem and say that 2 cups of water are 5 cups. So the answer will have an equation of 2/5 = x<n>- There will be the same amount of water left in both cups and that will be x in the final cup<n><n>----------------------------------------------------------<n>[20013-08] <n>------------------------------------------------------<n>### Instructional Design: <n>  - I created a task that students do on their spare time that can also contribute towards a grade <n>  - That will help the students to do something on their spare time to contribute and to engage with their peers<n>  - What this

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:It was a great rest, she had never felt this much what in the morning? Choices:  A: active B: hunger C: in motion D: wakefulness E: lay down<n><n>### Response:		(1) BH<n><n>#### Notes:<n><n>Answer and solution:<n><n>Answer: 3<n><n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class Task36.Task36 {<n><n>	public static void main(String[] args) {<n>		Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);<n>		String answer;<n>		String choice;<n>		<n>		do {<n>    choice = scanner.nextLine();<n>    switch(choice) {<n>        case "B":<n>        answer = "H";<n>        break; <n>        case "H":<n>        answer = ", ";<n>        break; 		<n>        case "A":<n>        answer = "; ";<n>        break;<n>        case "C":<n>        answer = "- ";<n>        break;   <n>            }<n>        } while(choice.equalsIgnoreCase("H"));<n>        // System.out.println(answer);<n>		<n>	}<n>}<n>```<n>

Each shoe pair cost him $8.00. He bought a total of $24.00. How many shoes did the boy buy?<n>### Response :<n>He bought 6 pairs.<n><n>Input :<n>A boy bought 3 pairs.<n>Each pair cost him $8 a total of $2<n><n>What is the boy likely to buy next?<n><n>He likely will buy more pairs.<n><n>### InputA: The total cost for a student’s course materials is $132.25. The student has $547 to spend on the course materials and other school supplies. Is one of the following equations correct? Choice A: 132.2 ÷ 547 ≠ 0.23 <n><n>Choice B: 132 ÷ 552 ≠ 0.02<n>Choice C: 552 ÷ 132 ≠ 0<n><n>Choice D: 6 ÷ 12 ≠ 0 <n><n>### Choice:B<n><n>Input : total cost for a student course materials $132.00<n><n>Student spends $547.00 <n><n>D = $552<n><n>### Input  A man paid $71 for his weekly groceries. He spent an additional $21 on gum. He had $36 dollars left. Was the man satisfied with his shopping? Choices: <n><n>A: Yes, since he had enough money left <n><n>B: No, because not each week is the same <n><n>C: No, because he likes gum <n><n>D: No, because he wanted to save the money <n><n>### Input<n><n>A man paid for his weekly grocery items with $71. He spent an additional amount of $21 for gum.<n> <n>So, he had $36 dollars<n> <n>Now, is he satisfied? Choose one of the answer choices below<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Choice A<n><n>Because he has enough<n><n>### Input A:<n>Three groups of boys competed in a

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where could a printer be used by thousands of people? Choices:  A: fishing camp B: hardware store C: engine D: your spine E: sporting goods store<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is choice C: “engine”. Damage done to an engine can involve the rod.<n><n>### Input<n>What has thousands of eyes and six legs? Choices A: a human being B: a mouse C: a spider D: a millipede E: an octopus<n><n>### Response<n>The correct answer is option B: “a mouse”. An actual mouse is the correct answer to this question and is a funny way of asking the question “what does a mouse have thousands of eyes and six feet?”<n><n>### Input Choice: A: How much is less than more<n>B: How much is more than fewer C: Fewer means more D: How much is more<n>E: In how many ways can ten people be divided into pairs? What is the answer?<n><n>### Response Choice A: A: Less than more<n><n>This answer is incorrect because it is confusing in its response of “How much is less than ‘more’?”<n><n>### Response B: B: How much is more(not fewer)<n><n>This answer is correct because it states that more is more, not fewer<n>### Example<n>The correct response is choice “B”: “How much is more?”. The definition of “fewer” is “used before a number to show that the number of things you are talking about is smaller”(Merriam-Webster). The definition of “less” is “used before an amount to say that one number is a smaller amount or smaller part of another number” (Merriam-Websterd). Since all of these options in choices A and B are incorrect, choice B is the correct choice.<n><n>### Choice C: C: fewer(not more)<n><n>The correct answer is “C”: Fewer (not more). The options in the answer are all incorrect.<n><n><n>[https://codingbat.com/prob/p106339](https://codingbatforkids.com/examples/java/Java1/CountingandComparison/P10633)<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		You've wasted your time.<n><n>### Rationale:You can't be fat if you're watching television. You can't get fat if you're asleep.<n><n>### Input :The total cost of a bookstore on sale is $30 more than double the sale price of the books. If the sale price of a book costs 20% more than its regular price, how much is a book that normally costs $40?<n><n>### Response :Its a book that normally cost $40 and the sale price of its $10<n><n>### Rational:The regular price of the book is $12. The cost of a bookstore that costs $30 more than its double sale price is $(30+$40). You take.20 away from the original amount to get the sale price. So the book normally $12 and it's 20% more from that when $2 is subtracted from $12. Therefore, the sale price is $10.

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:When you plant a garden you can harvest what to eat? How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Jackson is a popular city name, but the one with a governor's office is where? Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>I used two formulas to come up with the answer.<n><n>**First Formula:**<n><n>**Second Formula:**<n>$$<n>\frac{x-n}{4^{a-k}}   \times (4^{a-k+1}-1) =  \frac{1}{4} \times (1^{0-k+1}- 1)<n>$$

Choices:  A: dream B: knowing C: depression D: pleasure E: nostalgia<n><n>### Response:		1.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The number, 5(9!), is written on the board. You are asked if the number is evenly divisible by 2. How do you decide?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### A)<n>You have to find a number that is an even power of 2, a number square of 2. So try 4^2= 16, so 2^3, so choose one of the three numbers, so choose 4^2=16. Subtract, that is (5- 16) divided by 2.<n><n>#### B)<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>The number, **5x**9! **= 5(9!)** is written on the board (5x9 is also written on the board). You are asked if the **number: 5x**9! is divisible by 10. To find if the number 4x(4x9) is divisible by 2, write the first three digits of 4x and see if it ends in a 5 or not. The number is divisible if the first 3 digits end a 5. If it doesn't, then it's not divisible. If it does, it ends in 5, so 9x(4x9!) is divisible by 5.<n><n>### Response I<n><n>You need to add 2^5 to the number in order to get a multiple of 5, so 1125, then 1125 divided by 5.<n>### Response II<n><n>**17565, the 4th and 9th digit are adjacent, so it's divisible.** So the number is divisible by 9. But since we are checking if it's divisible by 15, we must subtract 15449 from 38557 until we land at 2, so 17493 -15.<n><n>## Task Three<n>Below is a task that describe what to do. How far does her walk home total?<n>Answer: 4.5 miles<n>```<n>#!/bin/python3<n>input_data = input().strip()<n>input_data = list(input_data.split(" "))<n>i = 0<n>while i < len(input_data):<n>    if input_data[i] == "miles":<n>        input_data[i]="KM"<n>    i+=1<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Justification:In the word problem, we have been given a little information regarding the situation in a question in the form of some digits. Then, we are asked to answer a question based on the information presented in the question itself.<n>### To find the answer, we would first have to determine the unit operation in the question. We first found the operation in the first question which was subtraction. Then we subtracted numbers from each other and checked for the answer.<n>### Using that process, we found that the units were multiplication and subtraction.<n>### By multiplying all the numbers before subtraction in the first question, we would multiply all the numbers in the question, and then subtracting we can get the answer. If anyone of the number in this question are negative, we will use negative operator - in the operations too.<n>### In the second question, we would add the numbers in the problem again. We can either add or subtract the numbers.<n>### <n>### Answer:  A: suffering <n>### Reasoning: we use the process of subtract the values in the units of addition and subtraction to find the answer.<n>## <n>## <n>## The man committed suicide because suffering and pain. he was unhappy since he suffered from a problem in his life. The suffering is very painful. For that reasons the man killed himself to avoid this suffering and sadness.<n>## <n>

I thought I was supposed to choose a choice! You'll have to do better than that."<n><n>**B)** If this answer was just said to me, I wouldn't really react: "You mean to tell me you've been doing this for months and you still can't tell the difference between something on the street and something in a place where people sell sex?"<n><n>* **C)** I'd probably just give a sarcastic response like: "Are you telling me you got a bird's nest in your pocket and can't tell who's doing the eating?" or a real question such as: "What does a whorehouse look like?"<n><n>* **D)** I'd be confused by this question and be pretty sure they didn't have sex on the street, so a sarcastic comment about something they probably didn't meant to say would probably be called for: "Are you suggesting that you can actually find sexually active people by cornering two streets?"<n><n>**E)** I'd definitely be disgusted by this, so I'd probably be just be honest with what I just thought: "Oh. So you were just asking me for the bird flu?"

Use the input, output and action labels found on the activity and environment pages, including the navigation bar at the top of each page, to help with this week’s lesson.]<n>* **[Write your instructions for each of the five tasks. Follow the prompts in the question to provide instructions for how to do each task.]**<n>* **[Answer each question, one per task (1, 3, 5, and 7 below). Write a phrase that tells me what is being asked, describe the scenario that supports the question, and finally, explain the answer. Each answer is a multiple choice question with four options. Each option should be explained as part of the response (using the phrase that tells me what it is, the scenario, and the answer). There is usually more than one option that fits the sentence, so if you make one option sound like a correct choice, you need to show that another option is the correct answer too. See examples for each question below.]**<n>* **Note: If the instructions for each of the tasks do not include anything such as the phrase "input and output" and instead has directions such as "type an answer on a post-it for the teacher to pick up later," then do not use the phrases "input and output" in your instructions or responses.]<n><n>* Question:How many birds have 9 legs or fewer?<n><n>* Description:I was in my bird cage area cleaning a cage when I heard one of the other birds singing. That bird's song has always seemed a little odd. It sounds like he's singing a love song, but I'm pretty sure that he means it as an insult to another bird, perhaps even my owner.<n><n>* Answer:I think that he was really singing about my owner.<n><n><n>### [Examples/Clarification: &quot;Here is how you should do this…&quot;]<n><n>* Examples/Clarification One: I think that he was really calling my owner a birdbrain. He always has to be pointing out how stupid the other birds are. Even the ones who are smarter

They are not necessarily brothers and sisters, but there are no more than 2 siblings between each brother and sister. The last sibling born is the youngest. How many siblings are there?<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>if all siblings are brothers and sister then<n>   B x S - 1<n>else<n>  (B x S) - 1<n>```<n><n>### Instruptions:<n>A man walks 5 miles from his home to work. He then walks 10 miles back. In total, how many miles did he walk that day?<n><n>### Answer:<n>```<n>if man walk 5 miles to work and 10 miles to come back at once time then<n>   W(d+d)<n>else man walk 5 miles from home to work and man walk 10 miles at lunch, at this time walk 5 miles (from work to home) then man back to work<n>W(5+5+10+10+5)<n>```<n><n>

Each plane flies at a different altitude but the pressure is the same on all the planes. For that reason, a plane is more at risk of an emergency situation in the air at a higher altitude than a plane that flies at a lower altitude.<n><n>### Do you agree? <n>### Statement:  A good book is one that, when you read it, makes you think.<n>### Agree Or Disagree? <n><n>### Statements:  A: I'm going to the store to buy a chicken. Choices:  S:  Fractions B:  Decimals  C:  Whole Numbers <n>### Response :<n>	B<n>### Instruction for response:<n>Write a response of "true or false" for each of the following.<n>### Input : If the first digit of a number is 3, is the number divisible by 7? Choices:  T:  False  F:  True<n><n>### Response : <n>F<n>### Instruction response<n><n>### Input<n>> What is the value for $602.59 + 5.59¢? Choices:  C: $608.18    F: $608   S: $609   B: $6080  <n>### Response<n>C<n>### Instruction - response  <n>Write the following expressions as fractions.<n><n>1. $2{/10}$<n><n>### Instructon Response <n>	Write expressions as fractions, so that the denominators are as small as possible.	<n>	Write all expressions so that they contain only the numerators and denominators from the denominator list.<n>	Choose between different ways of writing fractions so that they are equivalent.<n>	<n>### Input: A group of parents met together at the school to discuss the students' grades. The first half grades were good. The grades of the second half were bad. If 3 parents had good grades, how many parents had bad grades?<n>### Response : B<n><n><details><summary>Full Code</summary><p><n><code class="language-typescript" data-lang="typescript"><n>function main() {<n>    const [firstHalf, secondHalf] = [2, 8];<n>    const grade =<n>        secondHalf === 8? 2 : (<n>            secondHalf >= firstHalf<n>               ? secondHalf - firstHalf<n>                : secondHalf<n>        ) + firstHalf;<n>    console.log(grade);<n>}<n>main();<n></code><n></p></details><n><n><details

Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>The instructor provided the wrong choice. <n><n>### If you chose incorrectly, type the correct choice below:<n>  <n><n>### Input:# How many quarters are there on a dollar bill? Choices: A: 4 B: 7 C: 8 D: 14 E: 13<n><n>### Response:# The correct answer is B.There are seven quarters on a dollar bill.<n><n>### If your response is incorrect, type the correct response below:<n>### Reset your answer here.<n>  <n><n>## Solution: This was the solution to the question above.<n>### Solution:<n>**D** is clearly not included in the question. **C** includes zoo and rainforest but all the other choices include specific places. There were zoos in all these places but <n>they did not have to be zoological gardens. The same could be said of “rainforest in the great outdoors.”<n><n>**E** gives two options: “in the rainforest” and “zoological gardens.” The question only specifies that the option be from the rainforest.<n><n>**A** could be true if the monkey is a tree monkey. <n><n><n>**B** seems like a reasonable guess but the question says a bird not a monkey.<n><n>**C** seems like the clearest logical answer. However, there are no specific details about this location.<n><n>### Reset: Answer reset<n>### Reset answer:

"Everyone was at the party."<n><n>	The emphasis is on the fact that *everyone* was at the party.<n><n>2. "The party was for everyone."<n><n>	The same group of people is at the party.<n>		<n>This emphasis indicates that *everyone* means everyone who was invited to the party, not *everyone* in town.<n><n>### Sample Answer 1:<n><n>	"If he were rich, he would be able to buy the farm."<n><n>	The main focus is on the fact that the subject cannot buy the farm right now.<n><n>	"He could buy the farm if only he were rich."<n><n>	The sentence emphasizes the fact that the subject isn’t rich and can’t buy the farm.<n><n>### Example Answer 2:<n><n>	"Sam doesn't need food right now."<n><n>	The focus is on what the subject is currently involved in. *Now* refers to the present--a time when Sam has food and is not hungry.<n><n>	"Sam needs food now."<n><n>		The focus is on Sam's present need for food.<n><n>### Practice Writing 1:<n><n>"The dog was barking but he didn't bite the postman." The post is the main focus of the story.<n><n>### Writing Review<n><n>What is the main focus of your story?<n><n>### Sample Response 1:<n>I live at 534 Evergreen.<n><n>### Correct Response 2:<n>The main focus of this sentence is on the location of the subject.<n><n>### Explanation<n>The address is the subject. It tells us that the author lives at 534Evergreen. We do not learn the author’s name from

A bird died, and the bird's weight was 9 times bigger than the turtle's. What was the bird's weight?<n><n>### Response： <n>```c++<n>int bird=25*9;//bird's weigh is 25*9 (we change all 25 to 9)<n>```<n><n>### Input::A bookstore is selling books at 10% off of the list price. What percentage of the list price is each book worth?<n><n>```c++<n>for(int i=0;i<num;i++){<n>    for(int j=i+1;j<num;j++){<n>        if(A[i]>B[j]){<n>            C[i]=A[i]-(B[j]*0.1);<n>            B[i]=0;<n>        }<n>        else{<n>            C[j]=A[j]-B[i];<n>            A[j]=0;<n>        };<n>    };<n>};<n>```<n>The above is a program about how to find the percentage of the list price, C[i] is the percentage of the list.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The helm is not something you wear on your head. Rather, it moves the masts on what? Choices:  A: sailing vessel B: paddleboat C: ship D: motorboat E: tugboat<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input 2: How is a soccer match that ends in 2-0 different than one that ends 22-23 2-1? Choices: <n>A: they have the same score B: they have different scores C: one is in soccer and the other is in basketball D: they use different numbers E: they are played in different countries<n><n>### Response2:<n>E<n><n>### Instructions:If you have any questions or if you need help with completing this assignment, email me at [hbrown@uncc.edu](mailto:hbrown@unCC.edu) so that I can try to assist you. Thank you for your work so far!<n><n><n>### Feedback<n><h3 align="center"> <i><n>"If this is your first CS assignment, it's likely that you still don't know what it's like!<n>The good news is that everyone started by not knowing what they were doing.<n>And the only way to learn is to try and do your best, which is what this assignment is asking you<n>to do."<n></i></h3><n><p align="center"><br></p><n><n>---<n>---<n><p><i>By David M. Hutten @ University of North Carolina</i></p>  <n><sub><a href="https://www.math.ucla.edu/~crommer/CSCFall16/Fall16/hutten.html">Hutten's Homepage</a></sub><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		None of the others would apply, so honey seems like the only logical answer.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>John hates mosquitos for the same reason that I do. I hate them for a different reason though.<n><n>### Output:The answer is "honey".<n>Output:Incorrect. The answer is honey.<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The family was playing cards, what would be a reason for this? Choices:  A: amusement B: losing money C: charmed D: having fun E: win money<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input<n>In this situation, there is a choice between two solutions. Write a response that determines which solution(s) is/are most appropriate for the situation.<n><n>### Input Demonstration<n><n>If it is rainy, wear the hat.<n><n>Bring the pants if it is sunny outside.<n><n>### Concept<n>You are considering two situations wherein you must answer to an instruction wherein you must determine when one or both solutions are appropriate, and provide a written response. The given example describes two possible solutions when choosing what to wear during a rainy or sunny day.<n><n>### Response<n><n>If it is sunny, we can bring the pants.<n><n>### Comments:<n>The response is correct.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input <n>Choose which word or phrase fits into the sentence. Choices:  A. in a few minutes B. a few minutes C. in few minutes D. few minutes <n><n>### Demostration<n>Mary will show you how she got on the train. <n><n>### Comment's<n>The response is correct<n><n>---<n><n><n>### Input  <n><n>Choose which word is the most appropriate to use in the sentence.  Choices: A. the B. these C. those D. this E. those<n><n>### Demorstion<n>I wish that everything will go on smooth.<n><n>### Respose<n><n>I wish that the things will go smoothly.<n><n>### Coments<n>Response is correct<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The department store is located in the Northwest USA.  Where might it be? Choices:  A: new york B: big city C: town D: idaho E: shopping mall<n><n>### Response:		The department store is in the town.<n><n>input: The Department store is located in the northwest US. where might it be? choices: a. New York b. Big city c. Town d. Idaho e. Shopping mall<n>response: the department store is in the city.<n><n>### Input<n>> There are two pizza shops in town that take orders at two different prices per square foot. The first pizza shop charges per square foot, $2 more than the second shop. If a local bakery uses to boxes of 30 square inches of dough for their pizza shop, they will have to use 1 extra container if they chose the first shop as opposed to the second. How much more does a bakery charge for dough per quarter than the other? <n>> <n>><n>* A. $10.87<n>* B. $11.50<n>* C. $11.75<n>* D. $12.00<n>* E. $13.00<n><n>### Response 2<n>> The cost for a pizza shop is higher than the other pizza shop. Since the cheaper shop charges per square foot and they will be charged $2 more than their original cost. The original cost per pizza is $2 more than the other cost and we can multiply 0.5 * $10.27 to multiply by 30. That means you can multiply 30 by $7.0850 and then $11.825 to have the total of the first shop. That would be $269.78. So this is the cost of dough for one pizza shop.<n><n>### Challenge<n>> I will be calculating the cost of a pizza shop. There are many things to consider when making a pizza from the ingredients we have. The first price we think of is the sauce we put in a pizza it's $5 for a small bottle. That means we are going to multiply $5 $5=$25. I will then divide 25 by the amount of ingredients we have which is 30. This would yield a result of 25/30=$0.8333 of a small bottle $5/30=$6 with pizzas.<n>

What is the width of the plate?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Answer: 20 centimeters.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:In 1986, there were 3,000,000 more males than females in the United States for the first time in history. There were 5.1% more males born than females. In the year 1989, the total population was around 252,572,000 people, of which 115,671,000 were males and 136,901,000 females. If the ratio of males to females is 100 to 90, what percentage of the population was female?<n><n>### Input Two blocks are arranged horizontally. Block A is three times as tall as block B. Block B has a volume of 194 cubic centimeters. How many times larger is the volume of block A than the volume of block B?<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Input:The perimeter of a rectangle is twice its length and 8 times its width. The length is twice the width. If the area is 640 square centimeters, find the dimensions of the rectangle.<n><n>### Solution <n><n>### Input A bookstore in Portland, Oregon sold 13,400 more paperbacks than trade books in one year. One person has red hair, and the number of people with red hair is four times more than the number who do not have red hair. A sixth person

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many of the group are walking through the park?<n><n>Answer: 7<n><n>Input: A pizza has 12 slices. Four of the slices are cut into triangles, and six of the slices are square. How many pieces of pizza are triangles and square together?<n><n>Answer: Four triangles, 2 1/2 squares.<n><n>Input: Cindy has 2 books. She gives 1 1/8 book to Tara and 1 3/8 book to Sam. How many books does Sam get?<n><n>Answer: Two (halves of two books).<n><n>Input: Macy counted 582 cards in a deck. How many fewer cards are in the deck or half that?<n><n>Answer: Macy needs to count half the cards.<n><n>Input: The train left the station, and two hours earlier it arrived. When did it arrive?<n><n>Answer: It didn't - just departed. But it would have arrived two hours ago.<n><n>Input: Four out of five of the children on the bus are sisters. Two of the brothers are twins, and the rest of the children are brothers and sisters altogether. How many children are on the bus?<n><n>Answer: Eleven children are on the bus (five sisters, three non-twin brothers, two twin brothers).<n><n>### Instuctions Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>##Instruction:A. The function accepts an array as input and returns '1' if the input's element is '1' else return 0.<n>### Challenge:Input:10<n>### Challenge:<n>Summing up a value with the array<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a function named "sum(array)". The function should accept an array as input and return "1" if the value stored in the input is "1" else "0".<n><n>### Response.<n><n>function sum(array){for(i=0;i<array.length;i++){if (array[i]=1) return 1;if(array[i]==0){return 0;}}}<n>### Instruccions:<n><n>Summing up the Array <n><n>### Instuctions:Write a function called "double(number)". How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would a human expect to find manufacturing operations? Choices:  A: factory B: school C: grocery store D: band E: aircraft<n><n>### Response:		A:factory<n>

How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? Choices:  A: football stadium B: surface of earth C: car show D: opera E: movie<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```<n>Input:<n>A. Football stadium  B. Surface of earth<n><n>```<n>If we look up, we can see the birds that are moving, but on the ground we can see people walking that are also moving.<n>If we look down, we can see cars that are not moving, but we cant see people driving that are moving. That is why we cant answer C <n>The movies that we watch are only static and that is why we can see the movie that is not moving, but are not looking at people moving in the movie. <n>The person on the car show that are not moving are the car models and the people on the car show are moving because we can see them move there feet. <n>When we look at the opera or the band that play music we can see the instruments moving and the singer on the stage but we can see people walking behind us, <n>and they are moving with the crowd that is not moving.<n>As we see, we are only looking at the things that are moved that is moving, but they are all not moving. That is why the correct answer is A<n> ```<n><n>Input:<n>Input: There is a triangle and at each angle of the triangle, there is another right angle triangle above it.  Which of the triangles in the picture is below the square?<n> A: top left triangle  B: top right triangle  C: bottom left triangle  D: bottom right triangle.<n><n>```<n>If there is a square with right angle triangles above it, that means all the triangles are going to be right, but they are the right triangles, <n><n>we can easily draw a square around two triangles, but the point is to find the one that is on the square and that is D. <n>If we look below the three triangles that are on the square, from the left triangle, we can see that the right angle in it, is below the square. <n>The same logic goes for the right triangle, because above another triangle there is another right triangle. <n>The last one to be considered is the bottom right triangle, which is the triangle below the square, because above it, there is another triangle <n>that is an upside down triangle from the point of view of the picture.<n>That is why the correct answer to this question is D<n><n>```<n><n>### Input A math

But his target survived, that is the body armor.<n><n>### Reference:<n><n>[Teaching Kids Math: How Many More or Fewer Worksheets](https://www.theteacherscorner.net/lessons/how_many_more_and_fewer_worksheets.htm)<n><n>### Additional Resources<n><n>[CareerBuilder:Simply Write a Better Email](https://www.careerbuilder.com/advice/simply-write-a-better-email)<n><n>

Sam would get food to consume.<n><n>### Input:"154" is how much less than or equal to "365" days? Choices: A) 22 B) 35 C) 26 D) 45, E) None of the above.<n><n>### Response 35 it would be<n><n>### input:{x, y} equals { x: (-7), y: (+13) }. One of them has a magical ability that allows him to create two identical creatures that share every trait that were in the original creature: strength, health, and intelligence. Another can heal a person's scrapes at any time, but only once. You know they cannot bring a person back from death. Another is able to fly, but only a couple of times a day and with great effort. The last person can remove the power from both magical abilities. Which magic do you have, what magic can everyone else have, and if all abilities were used together, who would win this strange land?<n>### Response:This is an interesting game. I will explain what I know of the game with this in mind.<n><n>The game starts with 4 people and the player knows if he/she has the heal magic. This makes it so the player can’t die but does not heal scrapes. Another person can bring back a person from death making it very unlikely the game will end with 4 people remaining. Another person can fly that means the game does not need to stay in one place. The last person has the power to take away every ability. So the best magic to select by 1 of 4 people is heal making it easy to heal everyone.<n>

If the place was a hospital, the person could be in another hospital or the person's own hospital but wouldn't get to see the zebra. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The body requires constant energy to stay healthy. The body relies on both the foods that are consumed and the exercise that is performed. Exercise allows your body to release energy and keep your heart strong and your muscles toned. Aside from these benefits, exercise can also reduce your risk of heart disease, stroke, and diabetes, and combat stress and depression.<n><n>## Exercise<n><n>Before you begin writing responses and reviewing samples, take the [**Assessment**](https://youtu.be/6Ue4RkZKhvU). It should take you approximately 20 minutes to complete the assessment. To take the assessment, go to the **[Quizzes/Assessments](./2x-Quizzes/A91-1X-Assessments.md#assessments)** folder of the course website and follow the instructions given there. If you get stuck on a question, you still get a score, but you won't receive any instruction. When you complete the assessment, the correctness of your answers and the explanations for your inaccuracies are provided.<n><n>## Additional Instructions<n><n>### Task:<n><n>**Instruction:**<n><n>Write  two sentences that ask a question and two more that answer the question.<n><n>**Response:**<n><n>1. I love vinyl records, but I never knew how they were made.<n><n>### Your Response:<n>I’m glad I didn’t wait until I bought my first vinyl record to figure out how they were made. I had no idea they were made by pressing.<n><n>### What is a pressing plant?<n><n>### Response<n>A pressing plant is a building where vinyl records are produced. The plant uses a laminating machine to make vinyl records. A pressing plant is where you get your first vinyl record, your second one, and your third one.<n><n>### Why do music stores prefer vinyl records over digital recording?<n><n>### Vinyl records are preferred over digital recording because vinyl records are not only much cheaper than digital recordings, but also they also sound better than digital recordings do. It was difficult. (You should try to write the sentences as you would speak them aloud.)<n><n>### Output: A B C D E<n><n>### Input The catering company prepared enough appetizers for 130 people. If you plan each guest to need no fewer than 3 appetizers and the total cost of the appetizers is $9.84 each, then how much will food cost?<n><n>### Response 1 : The catering company will have to pay $16,961.20 for food. (You should try writing as you would speak the answer.)<n><n>### Response How much will food cost? A.	$16,962.20 B.	$16.962.22 c.  $16.961.22 d.	$66.738 e or f<n><n>### Output :<n>There are too many choices for food!<n><n><n><n>```python<n>import time<n>from typing import Optional<n><n>class Player(str, Optional[int]):<n>    """Simple string with optional integer value."""<n><n>    def __init__(self, word: str, id: int = None):<n>        super().__init__(word)<n>        self.id: int = id<n><n>    def __eq__(self, other):<n>        if not isinstance(other, Player):<n>            return super().__eq__(other)<n>        return self.value == other.value<n><n>    def __gt__(self, other): return self.value > other.value<n><n>def get_answers(questions: list[str], players: dict[Player]):<n>    for index, question in enumerate(questions, start=1):<n>        if type(question) == Players:<n>            players = question<n>        else:<n>            if any(player==question for player in players):<n>                return players[question]<n><n>def get_first_answer(questions: list[Player]):<n>   return get_answers(sorted(questions).__reversed__())<n><n>def ask_and_retrieve_answer(questions:list[Player]) -> Optional[Player]:<n>    try

Input: <n>	A: Montreal: 0<n>	B: New York: 20<n>	C: Ottawa: 2<n>	D: Toronto: 0<n>	E: 20<n><n>### Response<n><n>Your answer should be 20.<n><n>### Input and response<n><n>Input: A mug has 4 cups and 2 tumblers. There are 600 mugs. How many tumblers are there?<n>Answer: 75<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Anna, Emma, and Zack are playing a card game. Zack has 10 fewer cards than Anna and Emma together. If Anna has 20 cards more than Emma, how many cards does Emma have?<n><n>### Solution and response<n><n>When Anna has 20 more cards than Emma, that means Anna has 49 cards and that Emma has 49-20=29 cards. Emma has a total of 29 cards as a result.<n><n>### Code<n><n>def solution(n1, n2)<n>    if n1 > n2<n>        return n1<n>    else<n>        return n2<n>end<n><n>def response(n1, n3)<n>    if (n1 >= n3)<n>        return n1 - n3<n>    else<n>        if (n2 <= 0)<n>            return "The answer is 20."<n>        else<n>            return "Your answer is 20"<n>        end<n>    end<n>end<n><n>def question(cities, question)<n>    if question == "What city has the warmest temperatures?"<n>        return cities[cities.index(coldest)]<n>    else<n>        #return question<n>    end<n>end

One out of every 106 people living in the United States is of Mexican heritage, and in 2013, 35.6 million of the Hispanic population was of Mexican birth. The city and the state are known to have large Mexican communities. In 1776, the city of San Francisco was located 52 miles from El Castillo del San Carlos Borromeo de Carmelo Mission, the first settlement built by the Spanish in California. A Spanish mission was placed there because the Spanish wanted to control all of Southern California. Since Spain needed more territory to expand, San Francisco was intended to be the center of that expansion. During this time, the city was inhabited mostly by Native Americans and Spanish military personnel. Choices:  A: painting B: hen house C: california D: virginia E: movie hall<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In California during a drought, a fox is painting in the movie hall of a california hen house.<n><n>### Input (Written):<n>1. The question says there are only two choices so it can be narrowed down to be "either B or D", and since both options involve drought and birds.<n>2. In "A", the fox is in Virginia painting a movie hall. A movie hall, as the name indicates, is usually located in the city. California is not usually in the same city as Virginia nor does "california" and "virginia" appear in the same sentence.<n>3. In "B", the fox is painting a chicken house in California. Since this sentence makes sense, this is likely the right choice.<n>4. In "C", the most likely choice is an alternate wording of "B", as "california" still appears.<n>5. In "D", the fox is hunting for water in Virginia. This makes almost no sense, and the answer is definitely not "D".<n>6. In "E", the fox is looking for water in a california movie hall.<n><n>So, the answer is "B", since the fox is somewhere that involves drought and chickens in california.

Fill in the blanks to create a complete sentence.<n><n>If the first sentence is missing a preposition, you may use the same preposition once.<n><n>After completing the sentence, move onto the next, and continue until all 3 are filled in correctly.<n><n>### Example: If you buy an apple with ________ change, you might as well buy a whole apple.<n><n>### A: on<n><n>### B: for<n><n>The more you use them, the better they become. The more you use them, they more you get into a rhythm, and the better they become in time. So just as with athletics, music, or math, the more you practice, the better you become.<n><n>### B - 4th grade:<n><n>### C - 2nd Grade:<n><n>### D - 1st Grade:<n><n>The more you practice, the higher the quality of our work will be.<n><n>The reason is simple. The more we practice, the more skilled we become. The more skilled we become, the better our finished piece will be.<n><n>When we practice, we will not feel uncomfortable, hesitant, or even incompetent in front of an audience.<n><n>When practicing, the more mistakes you make, the better you will become.<n><n>## Input:Bill is 47% heavier than Bob. He is twice as large as Mike. At 2:00 PM, he stands 15 feet from the door. What does he do? <n><n>### Response<n><n>If Bob and Mike were not in the room with you, you would have no clue what they do. You would not be able to predict their actions.<n><n>If Bob and Chris were to enter, you'd be surprised by their arrival. They'd come and announce themselves at the door, not sneaking in from the back as quietly as possible.<n><n>If Sam enters and stands 12 feet from the door, he will see the back of the chair.<n>

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:They decided to hash things out over drinks, after enough booze they were able to get close on a few things and what? What % of his income is left to spend on other things?<n><n><n>### Response 2: B

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Who was the head of the branch yelling at? Choices:  A: owner B: foot C: subordinate D: base E: point<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is, E. The phrase that is used is, **point the finger at**. You were trying to find out who was the **head of the branch yelling** at...you can only be the owner or any other **subordinate**. However, if the head is yelling at a subordinate, what branch was the **head** of? There was no branch, the owner was the **head**. So, if the head is pointing the finger at a subordinate, the owner has to be yelling at the subordinate.<n><n>### Review:Complete the phrase,<n><n>    They are going nowhere fast, ___________<n><n>### Answer:<n>    with "so to speak"<n><n>### Input/Output:Read the following information and answer the following questions.<n><n>### Input<n><n>    1. One group of friends is trying to decide where they want to go for hamburgers and fries. All of the members are either going on foot or in a car. The group has 5 children, 3 of whom are going on foot. One couple is going in their own car. One family is going in their friend's, second-hand van, which has room for 3 people in the children's car seats. The car seats can hold two children each or three adults.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>    What is the total number of people going in cars?<n><n>    Number of children in the car with the family that is going in their friend's van?<n><n>    Number in the car with the other parents who are going out alone?<n><n>    Total amount of children going on foot?<n><n>    2. At the start of the year, every student in a large school received a single penny. The student with the highest coin collection at the end of the year left with the most money. In his room was a large number of pens, which were equally valuable. Some pennies had two dimes. Some two nickels. Other two quarters. After receiving his share of coins, the boy in the house across the street found that he had just lost his entire stock because his cousin had come by to borrow the silver quarters for a dollar. As a result, the penny collection of each student was now 50% richer. What is the new total value of all the penny collections?<n>### Answer:

His sister Jenny runs 5 rounds around the track and gets the same number of points. (1 point for each correct answer)<n><n>- - -<n><n>#### Answer 1 multiple choice question and 1 constructed response question. (3 points for each correctly answered constructed response question with total 4 points)<n><n>#### Write a complete sentence for each multiple choice question. (1 point for correctly written sentence)<n><n>#### Do not write any multiple choices as constructed responses, because they are already correct.<n><n>- - -
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:John was punching and punching at the wall but succeeded only in bloodying his knuckles. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>**Input:How many hours will there be tomorrow if there are ½ hour today?**<n>![](./Screenshot from 2019-11-20 03-42-16.png)<n><n>[Click here](https://www.exercism.io/java/input) for an input<n><n>### Input<n><n>2<n><n>### Direction<n><n>If 2 hours have passed since midnight, how long will it be til noon?<n><n>### Output: The number of hours to noon.<n><n>### Solution Code<n>```java<n>	Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);<n>	in.nextInt(); //The input is the number of days = 2<n>	int daysForNextNoon = 0;<n>	for(int i = 0; i < 24; i++){<n>		if(i <= 12 && i > 0){<n>			daysForNextNoon++;<n>		} else if(i == 0){<n>	            daysForNextNoon += 24;<n>	            timeToNoon = 36;<n>	            <n>		} <n>	}<n>	  <n>	System.out.println(daysForNextNoon);<n>```<n><n>##### Comment<n><n>1. Input in the form of an int is read from the console.<n>2. The number of days is read and the time is converted to minutes by multiplying by 60. We will need the days and time to calculate for 24 and 60.  <n>3. The variable daysForNextNoon represents how many days away from noon. We use the conditional statement to calculate for whether the hour is before or after noon.  <n>If this is true, it will return 1 since an hour has passed since midnight and another hour has passed since noon. It is then stored in daysForNextNoon.<n><n>4. We declare a new variable timeToNoon. This variable is used for the conditional statement in order to find the time difference. We subtract the current time of 0 from the time 24. The time difference is 36. We then add 36 to the daysForNextNoon, and the return this modified value.<n><n>5. Finally, we
