Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where are people likely to find food? Choices:  A: opera B: supermarket C: building D: conference E: apartment<n><n>### Response:		Based on the given information, B is the correct option. The opera house is an entertainment center usually filled with tourists. The supermarket is the most likely place to find food. A building typically has a kitchen to cook at or for a restaurant to feed customers. A conference center may be catered to provide meals for attendees. An apartment could be provided food from a neighbor, or the tenant could cook and bring their own food or purchase food at the supermarket.<n><n>### Input :A person is riding 200 kilometers (km) to a new job. When the person gets to the job, they turn around and go the same distance back. How long does the person ride in total?<n>#### Alternate Solution:<n>You know that the average speed of the entire trip is 200/2 = 100 km/h or 62 miles per hour.<n><n>You can use calculus by finding the area between the x and y-axes, which in this case we would draw as (x, x + 200). We want to evaluate dx with respect to x. Let this be dy. So we take the derivative of x2 and divide by 2, we find that dx = x + 100. Then we have dy = x. Dividing (1) by (2), we find that<n><n>d/dx = 2(x + 100).<n>#### Response:The area is 829,900 square kilometers (8,294,985 acres).<n><n>### Input - What's on your birthday cake? (Choices - C: Ice cream B: Orange Snap: Cake D: Candles E: Lollipops)<n><n>### Response - Based on the given information C is the right choice, because Ice Cream is a dairy product which is not suitable for most people with lactose intolerance and Cake might have dairy ingredients such as whey in the glaze or butter in the crust. Candles are not eatable but you can eat them.<n><n>### Alternate Solution - There are three options for cakes and candles and one is suitable for someone with lactose intolationerace. Hence ice cream is option C.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is likely to have more than one level in a city? Choices:  A: carpenter's shop B: video game C: garage D: total number E: building<n><n>### Response:		 C: garage<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In this example I got the numbers and wrote them into the equation. Since there is multiple answer choices I can use the range formula because I know the range will be the choice I need. Using the range formula I get the result of 50 which is the answer to the question above.<n>### [Link to sample response](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1z617wE6W0KO8XF1x26kSQ-J475xv4KLxZ83LZr843xY/edit?usp=sharing)<n><n>

Still, he would have preferred it if the job were what? Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		<n>- This statement is false. Present is a form of the past tense.<n>- It is a synonym of "prefer."<n>- The person prefers an available job to a close job.<n>- A more specific statement would be "John would have preferred having the job closer to home."<n><n>### Comments:<n>- Too wordy, use single word or short phrase.<n>- The use of "he was a bit upset" is redundant: "He was upset that he had..." might be simpler.<n><n>### Input(Wrong):  Jane needs some of her mother\`s blue dresses. There are 12 blue dresses. There is 1/4 as many blue and white dresses as there are blue dresses. There<n>are 7 black dresses. About how many dresses does Jane need?<n><n>**The wrong response is:** 40<n><n>**The right response is:** -25 blue dresses<n><n>**Correction to the challenge statement:**<n><n>Jane has 12 blue dress and needs some. We have 3 types of dresses (blue, black and white)<n><n>- 12 blue + 35 black + 35 white = 82 dresses in total<n>- Jane needs 12 blue + -12 blue = -1 blue, but that might be a negative number,<n>so we subtract 12 dresses from all dresses.<n><n>### Comment:<n>The correction sentence is not correct. We have not provided the original statement,<n>so we have to use the wrong correction. The correction above should be<n>-12 blue dresses<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>Input: Liz had some new gifts to give her friends. The cowpokes also buy:<n><n>1/3 pound of hay each,<n><n>1/4 barrel of corn each, and<n><n>2 barrels of animal feed.<n><n>How much does each cowpoke spend?<n><n>> _Challenge response:_<n>><n>> Input: Pete rode his bike 20 blocks past the post office. He got on the bus and went 15 blocks past the bank and got off. Then Pete walked 50 blocks back to his house. How many blocks did he do in all? __Answer__: 60<n>><n>> _What can change in a response_<n>><n>> Pete rode his bikey 20 blocks past post office. He got a ride and went 15 past the bank and got of. After that he walked 50 blocks to his house. __Challenge response:__<n>><n>> Input Pete rode his biyke 20 blocks from his house to bank. He got a ride. The driver dropped him off at the post office and went 15 block pass the post office and got some food. Pete walk 50 blocks back and got to his house __Challenge response:_ Pete walked 5 block from his house to the nearest stop. He took the bus to post office and rode back 5 block from post office to the bank. Then got his bike and rode 20 block to his house. __Answer__: 85 __What can change in a question__ Bank was replaced to the post office.<n>><n>> Input __What can change in an answer or a question?__ Pete rode his bicycle from his house 20 block to the nearest bus stop. He took the 15 block to the bank and went 5 block from the bank to the post office to buy some mail. He then got back on the bus and rode for 20 block to get back home. __Culminating response:_<n>> __What can change in the question?__

If each apples takes 5 seconds, how many seconds it takes to fill one jar?<n>Answer: 43,200<n><n>Input: Sally, Peter, Paul, and Mary each paid for dinner at a restaurant by placing a different number of bills in the waiter's tray. The total was $10. Sally did not give $2 because her bill was only $9. Peter did not give $5 because his bill was only 6. Paul did not give 10 because he gave $2 more than his bill. Mary did not give $10 because she gave 10 cents for every dollar that she gave. If Mary gave just one dollar more than Peter, how much did Sally give?<n>Answer: $5<n><n>Input: A certain school has 60 students. Twice as many boys are enrolled as the number of girls. Forty girls have 11 fewer brothers than the number of girls enrolled in the school. How many girls does the school have?<n>Answer: 82<n><n>Input: One afternoon after school, a truck dropped 170 gallons of paint on 70 bicycles and 3,000 automobiles parked in a mall. They were  full of joy.<n><n>Direcion:<n>Input: The boy caught the soccer ball. It was  flying in the air,  and <n>falling.<n><n>Answer in English, Using commas  and  capitalization in the proper  places:<n>The boy  caught the  soccer ball. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n><n>### Response:		E, build, but that's not how you spell build. The answer is A, make, and that's not a choice. The question is what they do with the building materials, not what they build. You can fix one.<n><n>### Input:"Alice sleeps in a bed that is full. She's hungry and has a cure of eggs to treat her sickness." Find the odd one? Choices: A: Egg B: Bed C: Sickness D: Eat E: Cure<n><n>### Response:"Beds are not full unless it's a full-size bed, which is too large for Alice," as this is a child's bed and she sleeps in it. You cannot cure a sickness."<n><n>### Input:(A) How many hours are in a month? Choices: B) 250, C) 480, D) 352, E) 30<n><n>### Response:(B)", that's more than 400 and 3 full days, which is 72, 84, 324, and you'd have to add the hours in the month with leftover hours to get the time in a year.<n><n>### Task:The correct sentence for the given number is A: Two hundred thirty-seven B: Forty-two thousand and forty-one C: Two hundred fifteen D: One dozen.<n><n>### Response :D, it is less than one month in the year of 12.<n> <n>### Task:Find the letter that doesnt belong.<n><n><img src ="https://i.imgur.com/RHJLx52.png"><n>### Response:I'm going to make an assumption the rest of the letters spelled correctly. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: eat C: go back to work D: make food E: get food<n><n>### Response:		B: eat<n><n>### 1<n><n>```python3<n>x = 9<n>y = 3<n>k = x+y #k = 12<n>m = 2*x #m = 4<n>n = 150 - (x-3) #n =147<n>g = 40 - (x-40) #g = 41<n>z = 211 #z = 212 #wrong number<n>s = 50 #s = 49 #wrong number<n>o = 3*x #o = 6<n>j = 13+13-5 #j = 5 #wrong number<n>i = 1/5*x #i = 1/4 #wrong number<n>d = 5 - (x+3) #d = 2 #wrong number aswell<n>h = 30 + 3 #h = 33<n>l = 140 + 7 #l = 147 #wrong<n>```<n><n>### 2<n><n>```python3 <n>j = 18 #j = 17<n>a = 20 #a = 8<n>l = 18 + 3 #l = 21<n>d = 20 - 3 #d =17<n>r = 3 #r = 4<n>v = 6 #<n>u = 18 +3 #u = 21<n>```<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If you're betting with a shark, where are you likely playing? Choices:  A: aquarium B: mediterranean sea C: south pacific D: pool hall E: pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		<n>> [Answer](Answer.md - text version of response)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:He was looking for the holiday decorations and found an old box of clothes up where? Choices:  A: attic B: trash C: loft D: closet E: box<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input : <n><n>### Response : <n><n>## Description:<n><n>This task uses a method called "fuzzy matching." Fuzzy matching means that the text in an input string is converted to a series of numbers and characters that reflect the relative frequency of each letter within the word so that "he" has a higher value than "a" or "e."<n><n>### Input Description:<n>An input string is provided in hex, base 16. The string must consist entirely of letters and numbers in capital letters, no punctuation. It can have any number of digits or letters. A capital letter or a digit has a value of 1, and the ASCII codes for the characters are used as such. For example, "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit" has the value 61+101+111+105+101+99+114+101+50+114+97.<n><n>### Response Description:<n>You are to find how often different input characters appear in the string. You are to return the frequency of each character within the string. If there is no specified input then return an empty string.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>import sys;sys.path.insert(0,"..")<n>from sympy import symbols, solve, exp, int<n>x=(input())<n>x = x.split("") # split into individual elements<n>x.sort() # sort into alpha-numeric order<n>a=x[0]+x[1]<n>a=x * 2<n>a+=6 # add 6 and 6- 12<n>a[1]=(x[0]+x*3)# find frequency and store in another variable<n>a+=str(x)<n>f =  int(a[1])# find frequency<n>if f <=1:<n>    print(f)<n>else:<n>    print(a)<n>```<n><n>**Example Input:** <n>Lorem ipsum dolor sit<n><n>**Example output:**  2 <n><n><n>**Solved**<n>```python<n>import  sys;sys.path=['..']<n>from sympy import symbol, solve, exp, int, int<n>x=(symbol('x'))<n>

There were 5 birds.<n>-I used one part of the equation 200 berrys *5 birds which gave me 1,000 berrys.<n><n>-How many berrys do Samuel's birds get?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instructoin:Write a summary response that compares the two short stories the giver and the story of an hour.<n><n>### Summary:<n>The stories "The Giver" and "Story of an Hour"are similar in the aspect that both of the characters are feeling trapped in their marriage, and in "The Giver" people don't really "feel" the emotions whereas they do in the story of an Hour.<n><n>### Response to the question: <n><n>### What specific literary devices does the author of "The Story of an Hour" use to suggest irony?<n><n>### The first use of irony is the author saying,"Her bosom rose and fell tumultously. She was beginning to recognize that there was something to life beyond...the walls of her apartment in 59 Rue Ferouger."<n><n>### The second use of irony is when the author says,"She was young, with a fair, delightful face, whose delicate texture was to her in an agony of fire."<n><n>### Summery of the story: <n><n>## Question 3:<n><n>### Write a summary response on question 2:<n>-The author wants us to know that even though Louise is at home, she feels the need to go somewhere and be alone with her feeling.<n><n>### The author also wants us to know that Louise feels alone. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the choice is A, then humans take in lungs and diaphragm.<n>If the choice is B, then humans take in oxygen.<n>If the choice if C, then humans take in abdominal muscles.<n>If the choice, if D, then humans take in air through the open throat.<n>If the choice would be E, then humans do not take in air. They exhale and not take in air.<n>---<n>### Explanation:<n>We can create a function to answer questions like those previously explained. We can create the function using if else statements and variables to store the final and intermediate results of division.  <n><n>---<n>### Function: If the human takes in air, the total ammount of air taken in equals the ammount of the last element times the ammount of the previous element.<n><n>--<n>### Function: When question is "What do humans take in?," answer is:  <n>---<n>### Variable: finalAir<n>---<n>function takeInAir(input):<n>    if input == "lungs and diaphragms":<n>        finalAir = 0<n>    elif input == "oxygen":<n>        finalAi = input<n>    elif input == 'abdominal muscles':<n>        finalAir  =\<n>        finalAir + 0<n>    elif output == "air E":<n>        finalAiry!= 0<n>---<n>### Main:<n>Initiate the variable "totalAir" to 0. Initiate the variable "index" to 0.<n>While the variable is not equal to 4: <n>    if  totalAir is less than 0 then totalAir += 99<n>    if totalAir is not equal to 0 then if index is less than input, then index goes up by one<n>    finalAir = totalAir times input<n>    input = input times input<n>    totalAir += totalAir / input<n>---<n>Else:<n>    print totalAir<n>---

Choices:  None of the Above  A: "I'm a pirate!"  B: "Don't rob me!" C: "Pirates are evil!" D: "I want you to stop what you're doing."<n><n>### Response:"Pirates, Beware!" means something like "watch out pirates" but can also mean "beware of pirates" in certain cases. "I'm a Pirate!" is a popular phrase used by kids to express happiness and joy, usually while playing.  "Don't rob/steal me!" is to be interpreted as "don't steal me" or "don't rob/steer".  "Pirates are Evil" is a popular expression to be used with kids to express a dislike for pirates.  "I want you to Stop what you're doing" means that you, the one hearing the sentence, should stop whatever you're doing and pay attention to the person speaking.<n><n>### Input:{ "a": 1,  "b": 2,  "c": 3,  "d": 4,  "e": 5,  "f": 6 }  Pick one of the words and add the other four. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where does someone lay with their leg elevated when it's broken? Choices:  A: spinning wheel B: on a ladder C: hospital bed D: legroom E: grand piano<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Why: A B C E D<n><n>### Reason: C<n><n>## TASK:<n>### A few notes to keep in mind for your response assignment.<n><n>- You must read and analyze the problem, identify the quantity that is being requested, and use the information provided.<n>- Be cautious in guessing a quantity based only on the information given. For example, it is possible for a person to have 5 pints of coffee without drinking it<n>- Whenever possible, provide work as it would be done for quantity 1, quantity 2, and quantity 3. Your final answer is based on your work.<n><n>### Example:<n>To solve the problem, you first needed to find out what quantity they were asking for, and then apply the equation or other calculation to solve the problem. In the 4.5 gallon problem, they did not state whether they wanted this in gallons, pints, ounces, etc... So you knew it had to be in gallons. By doing the math for all of the quantities you would find that it would be in ounces. For example, if quantity 1 was gallons then you would do the math for gallons. Then when you found your answer in ounces you would then multiply it by 16 to get your answer in gallons. <n><n>### To use a table or diagram of choice instead of a calculation, your work must be fully described. <n><n>## INSTRUCTION:<n><n>When I am ready to do math, I need to remember my table. Remember it is just a table with numbers and operations. The table tells me I put these numbers right here, right here, and here! How much did that guy say the guy gave him for that guy? Guess what the table does? It tells me with three numbers and whatever the operation might be (example - I might want 5-3, 5 minus something or 5-3 would actually be 5 divided by something and 5 plus something). You are welcome to draw a picture or use the multiplication signs to do your "math". You can not, however, go out and buy a book and expect to use that book. You can use a book that you are using in school or you might see it being used to answer the questions. In short, you can use a book to help you with your table

In this family there are 9 daughters, If aunt has 9 daughters, the family is a big famly because one female can only be the mother of 6 to 7 kids depending on how many babies she has. If each daughter has 9 brothers, the family is small for having 87 kids.<n><n>Explanation for How many brothers do they have:<n>Because there are 9 daughters and each having a brother gives you a brother for each daughter plus an extra one.<n>$$(\text Daughter+B\cdot\text Brother)=9+9$$$$=18$$$$=2$$$B$$$B$$$S$$S$<n><n>Explanation 18 daughters plus 2 brothers = 18+

A<n>6. B<n><n>### Instructions:How else can you answer questions such as these with the method of "pairs of fives?"<n><n>### Hints: You can break problems like this up easily.<n><n>### Answer:<n>1. You multiply the question, answer, and solution by 5 (or 5 x 5 for a harder puzzle). Ex:<n>> 9+5=14<n>> 4-3=1<n><n>2. You use addition, rather than subtraction, to find the unknown number. Ex: (9 + 5) - 1 = 14 - 1 = 3<n>3. You use the addition/subtraction method to find the answer to both parts of a double-question.<n>4. You subtract the second question answer from the first question number. Ex: (4 + 3) - 3 = 7 - 3 = 4<n><n>### Instutions: Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### A. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n><n>### Response:		If the choice(s) are C and D, enter "C and D" here. <n>### Output:136<n><n><n>## Task 2<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes how to solve a problem. Write the script that follows the solution with Python.<n>The challenge of finding the least distance from a given starting point to any other point in a simple polygon is known as the *Dulloptimum*  problem. <n>For example, consider a simple triangle formed with three integer points <n>A(0, 0), B( 1, 0), and C(1, 1). <n>A traveler who wishes to visit point A and then point B and then point C is looking for the least distance for this round-trip. The path <n>[0,1] gives the straight-line distance 1, whereas the optimal path is [0,0]+[1,1]=[1,0], giving a distance of 1/2.<n><n>An algorithm you can use to implement the Dulloptimum is to calculate the shortest path between each successive pair of endpoints (as in the above example). This algorithm has an exponential runtime because it makes O(N²) <n>calls to a distance function (where N is the number of locations), so it is generally impractical except for problems <n>where N is small (for example, a few thousand points).<n><n>### Instructions:Write the script that follows the problem, that is, "the problem," including the steps for solving the problem and <n>the description of the algorithm you used. This script describes a task.<n><n>### Explanations:There are three inputs: two points, the starting and destination points, and a number, which is the number of iterations or the loops. The Dulloptimum algorithm works, at a guess, by taking the shortest path between the initial starting point and the destination point, then taking the shortest distance between the ending point and the current point, including the starting point in both computations. This takes a number of loop iterations defined by the third input, and it works like this until all points are examined, after which the results are stored in a list.<n><n>### Output<n><n><n>## Task3<n><n>Below is the information that describes a task.  Write the script that appropriately completes steps for solving

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is the ground. A surface of the Moon's can only be found on the opposite side of Earth from the Sun. The moon's shadow moves across the Earth's surface in a day and night pattern. The sun's shadow can only be found during a solar eclipse.<n><n>### Input :A girl needs to wash her cat and brush it's hind feet. The cat then needs to be combed and brushed to make a nice appearance. How many hairs does the cat have?<n><n>### Response :The correct answer is 37. There are several things to keep in mind when doing this problem. The brush moves along the body and head of the cat. The tail and back legs are not separated, so you only need 4 combs and 3 brushes to do all the steps to make the cat nice.<n><n>### Other Instructions:How is the world 60 years younger?<n><n>Answer :The world is 60 years younger because everyday at midnight on December 31st, the new year begins and the calendar resets<n><n>### Instructions:A boy has to shovel 4 inches of snow. How long will it take?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: The boy has to shovels 4 inches of snow, so how long will it take? 4/2.65 = 1.5 hours<n><n>### Insttuctions:The year is 2045. You have just bought a digital watch from the year 2015. What year does this watch say?<n><n>Answer: The year is 2015<n><n>### Instuctions:You are 10 years old, then you are 20 or 30 or 40, etc, until one day you will be 400 or 600 or 1000<n><n>Answer: You start at 10 years old. then in 20 more years you become 30. In 30 more years, you will become 40 years old<n><n>### Instutuctions:You are driving your car and it hits a pedestrian. 1000 years ago, there are cars, you hit the pedestrian, and they were killed. 5000 years ago there were

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		Choose the letter next to the letter of the item that best answers the question. If there is no correct choice, choose E: planned. If no one knows how to ruin a surprise, choose C: expectation. <n><n><n><n><n>

She correctly uses the word "that" to refer to the noun "question". (Rather than the clause it modifies.)<n><n>The other responses have the major issue of referring to the question or the sentence, rather than to the noun (the question or the sentence).<n><n>She uses 4 digits for the answer, and shows correct understanding of the instruction about the number of digits.<n><n>Her explanation indicates an elementary grasp of the instruction, rather than a rigorous understanding.  If she had demonstrated full understanding, her explanation would have made more specific mention of the information that is requested by the instruction and the instruction's requirement that the quantity provided be 4 digits.<n>

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is the strategic gold reserve in the U.S.? Choices:  A: jewelery B: fort knox C: church D: jewelry store E: treasure chest<n><n>### Response:		<n>The U.S. gold reserve is currently located at West Point, at the U.S. Military Academy. There are 88.8 metric tons of gold, of which approximately 23.9 metric tons are in ingots and 64.9 metric tons are medallic, or coins.<n><n>### Explain:<n>This task demonstrates our understanding of the strategy in which students use information gained from a problem to solve a different yet related problem. The answer is at the bottom of the page.<n><n>### Reflect:<n>If students do not notice the relationship between the problems, they will not be able to solve the questions. This task is a basic review problem, which students will come across in many math problems.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>The gold is not all there because of the depletion of supplies from the Vietnam War, World Wars 1&2, and the War of 1812.<n><n>### Extension:<n>Another resource to find gold in the USA is at The United States Gold Reserve. This is a database of locations of gold where you can find more interesting factoids about where gold is, who owns it and how much is there.<n><n>### Related Material:<n>[The United Status Treat Reserve](https://www.pricenfitsguide.com/about-us/the-united-states-gold-reserve-50295)<n>

Each boy stands every sixth place in the line. What is the 100th boy to stand in the line?<n><n>### Response <n><n>The first boy should take a place between the first and the sixth boy in the line. The second boy should stand six places from the sixth boy making two slots. The third boy should stand in the next two slots. This is because he has twice the number of slots to fill. The next person should take seven slots while the next person would be 6 slots from it making two slots and the next person is six slots from it, hence, taking two. That is where I stop.<n><n>### Response

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If you socialize by having trivial conversations it is called what? Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		 Choices:  A B C D E<n><n>### Comments:<n>Would there be a better way to express how many blocks Pete traveled in all?<n>Input: In a room, there are green chairs, blue chairs, and white<n>chairs. There are 8 more blue chairs than green chairs. Two of the blue chairs are broken and cannot be used. If Pete is to sit on a chair and there is only one green chair left, then he must sit on a blue chair. He cannot sit on a broken chair. How many different chairs can Pete sit on?<n><n><n>Input: If the sum of a number and 7 is 128, what is the number?<n><n>Input: In 2 years, Seth will be 34. How old was Seth 3 years ago?<n><n>### Solution 1<n>---<n>You need to get the value of (age now - age three years ago) and divide by 3.<n>The solution below shows that.<n><n>> Solution1:<n>><n>``````js<n>var years = 2;<n>var <n>   currentYear <n>   = 2020;<n>var threeYearsAgo <n>   = 1980;<n><n>var  <n>   ageOneYear<n>   =  currentYear -  threeYearsAgo;<n><n><n>var threeYearsLater <n>   = currentYear - 3;<n><n>console.log("Seth is "<n> <n>, currentYear<n>, "years old <n>and was "<n>   <n>, threeYearsAgo<n> <n>"years old <n>3 years ago. "<n>  <n>, currentYear<n>   -  threeYearsThirtyYearsAgo," <n>years later"<n>);<n>``````<n><n>### Discussion 1<n>---<n>1.How can it be simplified?<n><n>2. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Utensils are used during what evening activity? Which of the following category is included in the group of dishes and eating utensils?<n><n>### Response;The correct response is F.<n><n>### The number of utensils required for a meal does not include the following: Choices: food, table, silverware, pots and pans, pantry, dishes and eating<n><n>### A: food<n><n>### B: table<n><n>### D: dishes and eating <n><n>### F: pantry<n><n>### <n><n>### Input A student has the following items in his locker: notebooks, scissors, crayons, and books. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What eastern state is home to a mountain? Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>Input:In the list above, which letter does not belong in the sequence? Choices: 	A: C B: E   C: F D: G E: H F: I G: J H: _____ ______ ______ E: J<n><n>### Response<n>I<n>Input:How many minutes were there in four hours? Choices: 1. 4  2. 96  3. 240  4. 384  5. _____ I 240<n><n>## Explanation:<n>The answer is 384.<n><n>This is an easy exercise, since we know the answer is 382 if the time was one minute.<n>The answer is 693 if the time was four seconds, and so on.  <n>You can't have the value of two of these (since one minute is 51 * 4 seconds and one hour is 51 * one minute).  <n><n>So the answer must be 384. For example 382 * 240 = 89920, which is more than the number in the 5th choice, so it must be 382.  <n>For example, 380 * 240=87200, which is more. And for example, 379 * 240 is greater than the 5th choice...<n><n>If the time is one million minutes (which can be the same as one minute), the answer will be 358,185,667, and this value cannot be greater than the value of 5.<n><n>If the time was 6,320 minutes, the answer is 1,387, 312 minutes, which is greater than the value of the last choice.<n><n>So the answer is 358, which is the same as 1,386,371 minutes, which is more than 5. So it must be 358.  <n><n>And a similar argument holds true for the two other larger inputs.  <n><n><n>### Input<n>The problem involves a sequence of positive whole numbers starting at 0 and ending at 52. The numbers in the sequence are obtained by taking the sum of the numbers from the previous two terms in the
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n>(1) For question, input is  A.<n>	1) How many choices are selected by the candidate?<n>	(2) Candidate select option number C and select D.<n>		1) Which option does the candidate select most often?<n>	(3) Which option does the person select most often?<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		C, desire to win<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the story by choosing one of the following endings.<n><n>### Story:The ________________ of the ___________ and the ___________ was coming to a close. There were more than ____________ students participating from nearly 20 districts. Although the final decision would not be made for 5 more days, it was obvious to most that the ___________ would win the __________ by nearly ________ percentage points.<n><n>### Ending:A: competition, students, votes, margin, city<n><n>### Instructor:This is called a ______________, or a ______________, when the answer is a number: 72.<n><n>### Response(s):A, question<n><n>### Instracutions:Complete each sentence below with one part to make a complete question.<n><n>## Instructions:Complete this question.<n>## Instructions:(1)  This is called an ____________________, or a __________________, when the answer is not a number: I’m ______ a glass of ________.<n>## Instructions：(2)  This is called a ____________, or a predicate, when it is asking what is going on:  If I were you, I would ________________________.<n>## Response:I’m drinking wine right now.<n>## Response:If I were you, I wouldn't drink so much wine.<n>## Response:This is called a verb phrase. <n>## Instructions:#3. These are called  ____________________, or phrases, when they are not asking for an answer and the last word tells you this: She had the courage, but she was afraid to speak out against the _________________________. (predicate)<n>#Instructions:#4, This is called a ____________________, or interrogative, when they are asking for an answer: What is the _______________? (predicate)<n>## Response:She had the courage, but was afraid to speak out.<n>## Response:What is the courage?<n>## Response:This has a predicate at the end telling you it is an interrogative.<n>## Instrucasions:#5, This is called a complete __________________, or sentence, when it has a subject, predicate, and complete predicate:  The children are afraid

Therefore, according to ancient history, humans have consumed grapes in various ways. The most basic and most important ways of fighting in war are combat and killing. In these ways, soldiers fight against enemies and try to conquer or destroy them. Therefore, these things can be considered as enemies. Soldiers join armies in order to kill enemies. Therefore, it was okay for him to use what he knew.)<n><n>2.P.M.: P.M. (The person who was talking did not know the opponents, but he knew how to say P.M. (standing for PM's). Therefore, he was able to say P.M.)<n><n>3.C.K. and D: C.K. and (This part is a name part of the opponent. It says that the name is C.K. and the first letter is C.)<n><n>4.D.N.C.M.P. It asked Marlene to write a program that would prevent future problems with the cake.<n><n>The task is asking students to program a task that runs before Marlene's recipe, which, in the task, was unsuccessful in making a cake. The task required students to review the code and identify any areas where programming errors caused the recipe to fail. Students were also told that Marlene wanted to make her cake more delicious by adding more frosting than the original recipe called for. Marlene did not want to waste any of her frosting. To prevent that from happening, she wanted to implement a program that would make sure that she used the correct amount of frosting for the recipe. Students must review the recipe Marlene has already created and suggest ways for her to keep the program from running the same error messages it did before.<n><n>An example of student code that works with this task is included in the solution document.<n><n>### Errors in Marlene's code:<n><n>#### Task Instructions:<n><n>In Marlene's Cake Recipe, the frosting measurement is incorrect: instead of 1/2 cup of butter and 1 cup of powdered sugar, it should be 3/4 cup butter and 2/3 cup powdered sugar because the frosting is called for in the recipe in ounces and Marlene's calculations for a 9x13 cake are wrong. Also, the recipe has errors because it was not clear whether the recipe should be run with cake already in the oven.<n><n>#### Examples of Student Code With

How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What are adult people usually expected to do? Choices:  A: sit B: being sociable C: talk D: drinking E: medium<n><n>### Response:		The answer is E (medium).<n><n>#### Question<n><n>A: When having food at a formal or high-class place, I usually choose to sit down on my chair because it will show the other people that you can eat politely and behave.<n><n>B: I do not believe that being sociable can be considered as a response to the question because the word sociable does not give any answer to the question.<n><n>C: I would only choose this if I am having a talk with other people.<n><n>D: I do not have any idea that drinking can be considered as an answer to the question. It seems impossible because when you eat something you can not drink anymore. If you drink, you can not eat again.<n><n>E: I think it is a medium so I will select this answer choice.<n><n>#### Answer<n><n>The answer is E (sit).

Each year, over 6 million people visit the aquarium, which sees an average of 15,000 visitors each day. The aquarium has received over $10m in recent grants and other forms of aid, and will be paid for through donations as well as a 2.5% increase in admission fees. The aquarium will be able to hold in 10 times as many fish species as the old aquarium. Which of the following could lead to the most financial improvement for the city?<n>```ans: C, D```<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The man on the street corner was showing off a wristwatch, he was trying to what it for drug money? How many blocks did Brandon walk in all.<n>Answer: 59Input: In a class room there are blue seats, green seats and white seats. There are 14 blue seats. How many seats are there in the classroom?<n>Answer 67Input: Alanna, Beatrice and Queen are preparing to a new school year and has been given books by their fathers. How many berris do Samuel's birds eatting in four days.<n>Answer: 90<n>### Output<n>The input that the user gives does not appear in the output.<n>### Explanation:<n>In a program, the input needs to be replaced, in this problem it is an instruction.<n>### Examples<n>Input: The man on the street corner is trying to what the watch for drug money.
